Speaker: Mr HOWARD
Title: AVERAGE WEEKLY EARNINGS
text: The honourable member for Barker rightly reminds the House of the quite unacceptably fast rate of growth in wages that be­ came evident when figures for increases during the December quarter were released recently. The rise in average weekly earnings has been revised upwards to 1 4 per cent and the earnings men­ tioned by the honourable gentleman rose at an even higher rate, by 1 5.2 per cent. It needs to be stated plainly that this development is one of the reasons the Government put to the Loan Council a proposal to increase the rate of interest on Aus­ tralian savings bonds. It ought to be made plain to the critics of that decision that if wages continue to rise at a rate which is inimical to the economic recovery which is so clearly taking place else­ where, the Government must respond with the tools that are available to it. One of those tools is the effective use of monetary policy. I take this opportunity to put at rest some of the nonsense that has been put around in the last few days about the effect of interest rate rises on the availability of money for housing in Australia. That is something of importance to honourable members on this, and I hope on the other, side of the House. The facts are simply that over the three months to January, lending by the major institutions-that is, building societies and banks-was 1 .2 per cent above the level of the previous three months and no less than 1 3.6 per cent above the level for the same period a year earlier. Those are the sorts of figures that ought to be kept in mind by honourable members when people charge in and suggest that the Govern­ ment's interest rate policy is having an unsatisfac­ tory, even drastic, effect on the availability of money for housing in Australia. The forces of supply and demand dictate that we, like any other borrower, have to offer competitive rates if we are to raise money. It is as simple as that. The Government does not intend to allow the critics of its monetary policy to get away with the totally false accusation that funds available for housing have dried up. The figures give the lie to that. There has been some restructuring between banks and building societies but the overall volume of funds available for housing remains at an ex­ tremely high level. Speaker: Mr FREE
Title: BALANCE OF PAYMENTS
text: Has the attention of the Treasurer been drawn to Press reports of estimates, pre­ pared by the Department of Trade and Re­ sources, of the effects of expanding resource in­ dustries on the balance of payments? Does he agree with the Department that increased infla­ tion and an appreciation of the Australian dollar are alternative responses to this expansion? Does he agree that these options would result in a 2.4 per cent increase in annual inflation or a 1 . 1 per cent annual increase in the value of the dollar, as estimated by the Department? What economic policies does he propose to pursue as an alterna­ tive to these unacceptable options?

Speaker: Mr HOWARD
Title: BALANCE OF PAYMENTS
text: The economic policies that I will continue to recommend to the Government are in substance the economic policies that have been followed over the past few years with gather­ ing evidence of success. Insofar as external poli­ cies are concerned, the contribution made to the growing competitiveness of Australian industry by the management of the exchange rate in par­ ticular is something which is now very widely recognised, and it is one area of economic policy in which the wisdom of decisions taken by the Government some time ago has been vindicated with the passage of time. Quite obviously the external policies that we followed have been highly successful, as indicated by the improved volume of private capital inflow into Australia, our much healthier external posi­ tion and the fact that so far as our balance of pay­ ments is concerned, contrary to what was alleged from the other side of the House as recently as 1 2 months ago, the Government has not found it necessary to continue the very large borrowing program that was commenced in 1 977. The pre­ diction made then that that borrowing program was required to supplement a temporary shortfall in the volume of capital flowing into Australia has been demonstrated by the turn of events to be ab­ solutely correct, and is another example of the success that we have had with the economic poli­ cies we have followed. Speaker: Mr HICKS
Title: LIVE SHEEP EXPORTS
text: I direct to the Minister for Pri­ mary Industry a question which I preface by pointing out to the Minister that the Australasian Meat Industry Employees Union has claimed that the live sheep export trade is causing a loss of jobs in Australian meat works and is calling for a ration of one live sheep for every sheep carcass exported. Is the Minister aware of claims now being made by. the union that live sheep exports are having an adverse effect on the nation's wool clip? Is that in fact the case? Mr NIXON The AMIEU has run a long campaign against live sheep exports. The basis of its claim in the first instance was that live sheep exports were affecting jobs for Australian workers in abattoirs and that, therefore, that trade should cease. The Bureau of Agricultural Economics conducted a study on the matter, as the House will know. The study demonstrated that in fact that was not the case and that, in the longer term, it might well be that jobs would be created by the continuance of the live sheep export trade. The fact of the matter is that there has been no dimin­ ution in requests from the Middle East for live sheep. I point out to the House that, despite the apparent presumption of the AMIEU, we cannot dictate to the Middle East what sort of sheep or sheep meats it buys. It has a preference for fresh­ killed meat. The fact is that we are supplying only some 28 per cent of the live sheep trade to the Middle East, so obviously there are other markets from which the Middle East would draw if that trade were to cease. 1 point out that, whilst some 5.5 million head of live sheep have gone to the Middle East, at the same time some 4.2 million head of carcass equivalent have gone as well. So as well as the live sheep sales, there is a significant sale of sheep meats. The AMIEU is drawing a long bow in its latest claim that the quality of the wool clip is affected by the fact that approximately 6 million wethers are going out of the country each year. I dispute that it is affecting the quality. It may well be affecting the composition of the flock and there may well be an increasing percentage of ewes in the total flock, but I dispute that it is affecting in any way the quality. The fact is that over the years there has been a change in the composition of the sheep flock of this country and the Australian wool grower has always met the demands placed upon him for the types of wool required by the world's wool users, so I think the AMIEU is draw­ ing a very long bow on this issue. Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: REPRESENTATIVES
text: For the information of honourable members. I present the third annual report of the Department of the House of Rep­ resentatives. The report deals with activities of the Department in 1 980 and refers to business and activities of the House itself. An important devel­ opment within the Department in 1 980 was the expansion of the existing familiarisation pro­ cedures for new members into a more detailed seminar program. Following the general elections last year, the seminar program was arranged by the Clerk of the House, with involvement by my­ self, the Deputy Speaker, the Whips and long­ serving members of all parties, and officers from the parliamentary and Executive departments. Both new and existing members have expressed support for the concept. Seminars in future will be held before the first sitting of each new Parliament. A major feature of the 1 980 parliamentary year was the selection of a designer for the new Parlia­ ment House, and approval by Parliament to pro­ ceed with preparation of a detailed design and with the site. The building program has now begun after an extensive planning period. Site work has almost reached the building level on the western side and the concept of the final position­ ing of the main structure is emerging. Estimates committees operated again in 1 980 under sessional orders amended to incorporate a number of suggestions for improving the working of the committees. Different opinions are held among members as to the role of Estimates com­ mittees and further modification of the sessional orders may be necessary when the committees are re-established in this Parliament. Legislation com­ mittees operated to a limited extent in 1 980. Members of both sides of the House continue to assess these committees as a valuable addition to the legislative process. The sessional orders have been re-introduced in this Parliament with some minor amendment. By analysing its experience and adjusting where necessary, the House con­ tinues to refine its rules of procedure along the road of parliamentary reform. I have previously stressed my commitment to parliamentary reform. 1 re-assert that commit­ ment, and will continue to work, for example, towards the adoption of the Westminster conven­ tion relating to the Speaker, the televising of pro­ ceedings and a revision of our Standing Orders so that committees can perform the tasks we expect of them. The recent reforms of Parliament's pro­ cedures have not been great. The parliamentary institution has exhibited a resistance to change and the fact that there has been reform at all is a major advance. We must ensure that we continue to examine critically our own procedures and proposed avenues of parliamentary reform. We must implement revised practices where necess­ ary. We must ensure that our procedures, or in­ itial moves toward reform, are not allowed to atrophy. The public is generally critical of the role of Parliament today. There is a continuing demand for Parliament's reform. The rising levels of edu­ cation and sophistication among the public have led to greater expectations of the Parliament. We must ensure that we respond to these expec­ tations, and mould a parliamentary institution which more effectively monitors the activities of modern day government. T commend this report to the House. NA Assent to the following Bills reported: Commonwealth Teaching Service Amendment Bill Long Service Leave (Commonwealth Employees) Amend­ ment Bill 1981 . Despite that situation a contract was let for the supply of 202 visual display units. It was entered into with Information Electronics Ltd on 28 May after this report had been made. That was a disas­ trous decision. Honourable members will recall that it is in that context that we lead up to the situation in September, to which I have alluded, with the terminal printers. Flowing from the De­ partment's decision not to extend SAMIN nationally because of the unavailability of time it was stuck with surplus equipment. In September we wanted the Department to explain what it was doing about disposing of equipment which had been ordered on the basis that the Department was to have a national system. But having made a decision before August not to have a national sys­ tem, the Department had to go about the business of disposing of that equipment. The evidence which I have put before the House shows-the revised estimates at the end of December last year, at which the Minister looked-that the Department was operating on the equipment necessary only for Brisbane. It had to get rid of the equipment because it had made the decision not to go national. Yet this Minister tabled a report on 2 December 1 980 and, on three occasions in this House answered questions on the basis that there still might be an extension of SAMIN possibly on Mandata. On 1 1 March the answer he gave to me was that there still may be a decision to extend SAMIN on Mandata when, in fact, the decision had been taken not to extend and the Department had actually engaged in the disposal of equipment which was necessary to en­ able that decision to be taken. In the very short time available to me let me just anticipate the further misrepresentation in which I believe the Minister may try to engage. I warn him that I know all the facts and he had bet­ ter be very careful about attempting to mislead this House again. He may try to say that a thing called Job Bank may be a basis upon which there may be some extension. I am waiting with eager­ ness to see what he has to say about that because we know the answer. It is one which does not sus­ tain in the slightest way the lies which he perpe­ trated in this House. The final point I wish to make before my time expires is that: if the Minis­ ter wants to mislead this House about the evalu­ ation that has been undertaken in Brisbane I hope he proceeds upon that basis because we will answer him with the facts. text: Stirling-Minister for Employ­ ment and Youth Affairs) (3.35)-1 welcome the opportunity to debate this matter, which was set down on the Notice Paper during the last sitting week of this Parliament. As I will demonstrate, there is no foundation for the assertions so extravagantly made by the honourable member for Wills ( Mr Hawke) . Having regard to the tone of his speech and his actions in the House; I might say that those assertions were rather hysterically made. The honourable member for Wills alleged on a number of occasions that I misled the Par­ liament on the future development of the Statisti­ cal and Management Information Network, SAMIN-not a fish to be played with but some­ thing to be seriously considered. It is the Statisti­ cal and Management Information System cur­ rently operating in the Brisbane offices of the Commonwealth Employment Service. The honourable gentleman suggested that a decision had been taken that SAM IN would not be' ex­ tended to operate on a national basis. I will quote directly from a question asked by the honourable gentleman on 1 1 March this year. He asked: Is it a fact that a decision was taken by the Minister's De­ partment prior to September last year I stress thisto abandon the planned introduction of the Statistical and Management In formation N etwork on a national basis . . . The ansWer to that question is clearly no. No de­ ' cision has been made to abandon SAMIN on a national basis. It is the usual practice of the Oppo­ sition to attempt to besmirch the reputation of Ministers with wild and unfounded allegations. I acknowledge that that is part of the game of poli­ tics. We deal with such things in the House not every day but as they come along. However, in this case the allegations made by the honourable gentleman reflect on the competence and integ­ rity of officers of my Department. I take such alle­ gations very seriously. The honourable gentleman has challenged statements in the annual report of my Department for the year 1 979-80. That is an attack upon the integrity and honesty of officers of my Department. I say that because SAMIN is a system designed to aid departmental management. Explanations of its development have been given to committees of Parliament and to the public. These expla­ nations have been based on the understanding that SAMIN would go national after an evalu­ ation . It has always been thus and it still is the case . . By way of background, SAMIN was introduced in Brisbane as a system to keep the management of the CES better informed of the volume and nature of transactions conducted by its officer�. Although a system of this kind had been con­ sidered for some time, the discovery that the Pub­ lic Service Board's Mandata system at that time had spare automatic data processing capacity led to SAMIN 's development . SAMIN was introduced in September 1 979 in Brisbane to test its efficacy and efficiency. At that time Mandata was developing. At a point where SAMIN was reasonably well developed in Brisbane, early last year, consultants-the consultants to which the honourable gentleman referred, Burroughs Ud­ were hired by the Department to assess the system and the scope for its further development. Those consultant's reports which were avail­ able to the Department in mid-1 980 led to the De­ partment taking the view that Mandata would not continue to have the spare capacity, the basis on which SAMIN was originally implemented, to allow SAMIN to be operated nationally on that equipment. If at that time SAMIN was to be ex­ tended nationally, it would have been necessary to obtain additional central ADP equipment. In other words, it would have been necessary to up­ grade Mandata equipment. The estimated cost was about $ 1 . 7m. The Department decided not to seek additional ADP equipment as its own pro­ posals for acquiring that equipment for the Com­ monwealth Employment Service, the Job Bank system, of which public notice has been given, were already well advanced. I was informed of the Department's decision in early July 1 980 and I endorsed a course of action which is well sum­ marised in an information bulletin of September 1 980 of the National Director of the Common­ wealth Employment Service. That bulletin, dated 8 September 1 980, was circulated. to CES staff members throughout Australia. I will .quote from one passage of the bulletin which dealt with CES computerisation and described what was happen­ ing regarding Job Bank. It pointed out that SAMIN had by then been implemented success­ fully in all Brisbane offices and, after initial teeth­ ing problems, was operating reliably. It stated: Unfortunately, there are difficulties in extending SAMIN beyond Brisbane in the near future. The Public Service Board'8 MANDATA computer which processes SAMIN data has no further spare capacity. Consequently, SAMIN could only be extended beyond Brisbane by upgrading MANDATA's computer or acquiring other computing resources. I draw the attention of the House to that passage particularly in relation to the passage at the end of the answer I gave on 1 1 March 1981 . I stated: At that timeNamely, a fter a n evaluation was to be completeda decision will have to be made as to whether the Mandata computer or some other computer will be used. After I gave that answer I sought from my De­ partment the papers relating to the matter in order to refresh my memory and to check the ac­ curacy of my statement. The honourable member for Wills tries to make something of that, but the facts are that iri July the advice before me from my Department was that if the Government was prepared to spend $ 1 . 7m to upgrade Mandata, SAMIN could be extended nationally. The alternative was to extend SAMIN nationally by using other computing resources. The first reviewed the technical aspects of the system and the second reviewed its impact on the work load of the CES. The techni­ cal review was completed in late 1 980. text: Gellibrand) (3.59)-The Oppo­ sition is greatly concerned at the likelihood of a further round of interest rate increases of the order of one per cent or so. We are so concerned because of a decision made by the Government yesterday evening in which it announced an in­ crease in the Australian savings bonds interest rate from 1 1 t per cent to 1 2t per cent, a rise of NA three-quarters of a per cent. That is by far the highest level that the interest rate on savings bonds has reached since they were introduced. The savings bonds rate traditionally has been closely associated with the building society rates. When there has been movement in the savings bond rate it has been normal for there to be an in­ crease in the building society rate, if the savings bond rate movement was upward, and with the increase in deposit rates by building societies in­ evitably there has been an increase in their loan rates and therefore higher loan repayments for home buyers purchasing their homes through building society loans. That, of course, is tremen­ dously important for all those buying homes Rocher, A. C. Ruddock, P. M. through building societies or intending to do so. It is also important in relation to those who would be seeking bank finance-more so now since the decision of the Government last December to deregulate deposit rates by the banks. Now we have the situation where the banks can also attempt to keep pace with savings bond in­ creases by increasing their rates on deposits with­ out having to depend on the Government to ap­ prove increases in those rates. Of course, there is a limitation in the sense that there is still control on the lending rate so that the extent to which the banks can increase their deposit rates is limited to some extent by that fact. Of course, that means that the banks then put pressure on the Govern­ ment for an increase in those loan rates. At present we are greatly concerned that given that increase in savings bond rates the banks will be pressuring the Government very vigorously for an increase in their loan rate. That has become particularly important since the Government's decision to deregulate bank deposit rates last December. Since that time there has been a sig­ nificant increase in bank deposit rates. Savings bank investment account rates are up from 9 per cent last December to l O t per cent now--an in­ crease of 1 t per cent. Rates on fixed deposits by trading banks are up by at least three-quarters of one per cent, in some cases more. This indicates that there was a strong increase in bank deposit rates before last night's decision to increase savings bond rates. Therefore, even before the Government made its decision to increase those savings bond rates, which was announced last night, there was pressure on the Government to allow a further increase in the loan rates charged by the banks for overdrafts and home loans. This has, of course, a very significant impact indeed on the building industry and on the housing situation at large. Of course, the reason those people are excluded is simply that they cannot meet the re­ payments. To obtain a $25,000 loan from a savings bank at 1 2+ per cent interest over 25 years on the basis that these repayments are no more than 25 per cent of gross earnings, which is the normal provision required by banks, a buyer would need a gross weekly income of $273 a week. Average weekly earnings are only just slightly above that amount at $278 a week. Over 60 per cent of wage and salary earners earn less than av­ erage weekly earnings. Quite obviously the ma­ jority of wage and salary earners are excluded from obtaining a home loan of that normal kind at the likely interest rate of 1 2+ per cent. Therefore, we find the great impact on the housing market which I mentioned. Of course, this applies not only in relation to home purchase but also it creates enormous prob­ lems in the home renting area, particularly when the Government has been slashing funds for pub­ .lic housing and therefore creating a shortage of rental accommodation. That plus the exclusion of people from the ability to buy puts enormous pressure on rents which are currently increasing rapidly and are likely to increase even more if these policies are pursued, as apparently they will be. Therefore, in the housing area this has a very significant impact indeed and an impact on the building supplies industry and through that the economy in general which, of course, is also affected by higher interest rates increasing the price of investment and therefore making less in­ vestment likely, having impacts on employment. Why then do we have this interest rate spiral which is clearly so damaging? There are basically three reasons as we see it. Firstly, there are the monetarist policies of this Government. This Government is increasingly monetarist in its ap­ proach at a time when such policies are increasingly being exposed as disastrous and unworkable. The rise in the savings bond rate is designed enable the Government to keep the money supply growth within its budgeted rate of 9 to II per cent. The Treasurer has decided to increase the rate by another three-quarters of a per cent to bring in more money, so he can keep the rate of growth of the money supply down to his target rate. This is in contrast with the position in pre­ vious years. Last year the rate blew out by some 3 per cent more than the target or budget rate. In the previous year there was a similar blow-out, but this year the Government seems to be more determined to ensure that there is no blow-out of the money supply rate of growth. Therefore, we can say that it is increasingly monetarist in its proach. This is at a time when all over the world great concern is being expressed about the auth­ enticity of monetarist policies, particularly in the United Kingdom, where it is a subject of enor­ mous discussion. The Government says that we need to restrict the rate of growth of the money supply to reduce inflation, but there is no evidence here, or any­ where, of a clear relationship between the rate of growth of money supply and the rate of inflation. I challenge the Treasurer to produce one skerrick of evidence that there is a clear relationship be­ tween the rate of growth of money supply and the level of inflation. One certainly cannot find it in Australia's history or in the history of any other country, so far as I am aware. Indeed, there is no economic theory which holds that there is such a relationship. Not even the Friedmanites in their basic economic theory hold that there is such a close relationship. All we have is the basic re­ lationship, adhered to by economists for many years, that the amount of money in the economy, times its velocity-the speed with which it is turned over-equals the quantity of goods produced as determined by the price level of those goods and services. It is a simple, basic relation­ ship. It does not follow that if M, the amount of money in the community, is reduced the price level is also reduced. The quantity of goods and services in the community might be reduced. Indeed, that conclusion was reached by two Adelaide economists, Davis and Lewis, in an article published in The Australian Monetary System in the 1 970s, edited by Michael G. Porter. In the chapter on money and income determi­ nation they say, speaking of their economic study: . . . these results suggest that the Liberal-NCP Govern­ ment's strategy of pitching the monetary growth rate target well below the ongoing rate of growth of consumer prices is likely to have a more reliable impact upon output than upon prices. In other words, if one follows this Government's monetary policy one is more likely to reduce out­ to put than inflation. That is what we are seeing at present in the real world. We are seeing it in Australia while this Government is pursuing its monetary policies of 1 976-77 and 1 977-78. It has let them blow out a bit since. We have certainly seen it in the United Kingdom, where those mone­ tarist policies are continuing in a period of high inflation and devastating impact on output and employment. What does undoubtedly go with monetarist policies is high interest rates; there is absolutely no doubt about that. This is because inflation re­ mains high and that tends to bid interest rates up. ap­ It is also because a contraction of the rate of growth of the money supply creates a shortage, so its price, that is, interest rates, is bid up. I refer honourable members to a cable, received today from Europe, on a statement by the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe. It states: The United Nations Economic Commission for Europe (ECE) today warned governments that reliance on tight mon­ etary controls to tame inflation without an incomes policy could lead to a heightening of social conflict . . . The report suggested that monetarist strategies being fol­ lowed by several governments that have turned away from in­ comes policies could increase social strains caused by higher unemployment, and said the effectiveness of such an approach was yet to be proven . . . The survey added: 'One consequence of the present mone­ tarist strategy has been a widespread escalation of interest rates, which have now reached very high levels, particularly in the United States'. We have there evidence from the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe that mone­ tarist policies are leading to a declining economy and higher interest rates. That situation is likely to occur here, although resource development pro­ vides an offsetting factor in regard to the level of economic activity. Deregulation is another reason we have such spiralling interest rates, a matter to which I re­ ferred in my opening remarks. If the Government persists in its support for deregulation in the middle of the year, when the Campbell committee report comes down, we can expect further in­ creases in interest rates. The banks, in their sub­ mission to that committee said that deregulation would lead to higher interest rates.

text: Bennelong-Treasurer) (4. 1 5 ) - [ welcome this matter of public import­ ance because of the opportunity it affords to ana­ lyse the different approaches of the Opposition and the Government on the question of interest rates, and to draw out the absolute unrealism of the approach that is taken by the honourable member for Gellibrand ( Mr Willis) . It is an ap­ proach, I might add, that brings him into some conflict with statements made until fairly recently by his own leader, the honourable member for Oxley ( Mr Hayden) who certainly, when he was Treasurer, and since he has become Leader of the Opposition, acknowledged the link between the rate of growth of the money supply and the level of inflation. Therefore, my opening point is that the honourable member for Gellibrand has indicated a very significant difference between his approach and that of the Leader of the Oppo­ sition who, in his calmer moments and when bet­ ter advised, knows as well as do honourable members on this side that there is a very import­ ant link between the rate of growth of the money supply and the level of inflation. Obviously, no honourable member likes high interest rates. Government members are as con­ cerned as anybody else that interest rates should now be higher than they were some months ago. We are naturally concerned, in particular, about the level of interest rates in the sensitive areas affect Australian home buyers. But in a debate like this we have to ask ourselves some fundamen­ tal questions. We have to ask what causes interest rates to go up and whether there are any realistic alternatives to the policy that the Government is currently following. The honourable member for Gellibrand might acknowledge that the ultimate pressure on the level of interest rates in the com­ munity is the pressure of supply and demand. He would surely acknowledge that ultimately the price of money is determined by the volume avail­ able and the demand for it. It follows that those who are interested in bringing down the level of interest rates must demonstrate a capacity to fol­ low policies which reduce the demand on funds available for lending. That is the central point in any debate on interest rates. It is no good bewailing the level of interest rates, or saying that they were at a certain level some months ago and are now at another. It is necessary, if we are to bring down the level of interest rates, to produce a coherent strategy which is better than that followed at present. The first thing that any government has a responsi­ bility to do in regard to interest rates is to curb its appetite for borrowing funds from those that are available in the community. It is sometimes for­ gotten by people on the other side that govern­ ments, by their own activities, have an effect on the amount of money that is available and its price. Every time a government spends more, through borrowing, than it raises through tax­ ation, it puts pressure on interest rates. Every time governments do more than they ought to do in providing services they enter into open compe­ tition with financial institutions which provide money to Australian home buyers. Therefore, every politician on the other side who bewails the price of finance to home buyers ought to look to his own commitments in the public sector-and none more so than the honourable member for Gellibrand who is on record, as every honourable member on this side knows, as being in favour of a much larger public sector. He stands for increas­ ing the competition by the government sector for funds and therefore for forcing up further the price of money. He knows, as well as we do, that when governments increase their own demands for funds they increase competition; that there­ fore they have an effect on the price of money. Anyone who wishes to know who stands for re­ ducing pressure on interest rates in Australia must consider the comparative policies of political par­ ties as to the size of the public sector. Lower deficits, reduced borrowing demands and a that smaller public sector borrowing requirement ultimately reduce the pressure imposed by the government sector. The answer of the Opposition is to ignore that fact, although some, and in par­ ticular the honourable member for Reid ( Mr Uren) , if his questions of some ten days ago are any guide, would have us reduce some of the pri­ vate sector demands for funds so that more could be made available for the public sector. If the ar­ gument is about the size of the private sector, or the public sector, in the economy let us at least have an honest debate on whether the public sec­ tor should be larger or smaller. Let us not cloud the issue. If we have a certain volume of money available for lending in the com­ munity and the public sector demand for it is increased, then there will be as much impact on the price of that money as if the private sector's demand for it were increased. That is why this Government has been so concerned to reduce the overall demand made by Government on funds available in the community. That is why we have been concerned about the size of the Budget deficit. That is why since 1 975, largely through what has been done to reduce the size of the Budget deficit, we have reduced the overall public sector borrowing requirement from 6.5 per cent in 1 975-76 to an estimated 3.4 per cent in 1 980-8 1 . Most of that reduction has been on account of what the Commonwealth Government has done. In 1 975-76 the Commonwealth sector borrowing requirement accounted for 5 per cent of gross domestic product; in 1 980-8 1 that figure was down to only 1 . 5 per cent. In 1 975-76 the State and local sector accounted for 1 .4 per cent and that figure has risen to 1 .9 per cent in 1 980-8 1 . Over the last five years we have seen a reduction in the overall public sector borrowing require­ ment, all of which has been due to the reduction by the Commonwealth Government of its own Budget deficit and its own borrowing require­ ment. In fact, there has been an increase in the States. The Commonwealth has carried more than the lion's share of reducing the public sector borrowing requirement in the Australian com­ munity and has played more than its part in re­ ducing government pressure on funds. Of course, interest rates are higher now than they were some years ago. They are higher now than when the party to which the honourable member for Gellibrand belongs was in office. That is for the simple reason that when the Australian Labor Party was in office it cared not about how the money supply grew or about the level of infla­ tion but it was quite prepared to allow a huge un­ funded Budget deficit. It did not care one bit about the growth of the money supply, it did not care one bit about the effect of inflation and it did not care one bit about the consequences of that for investment and employment in the Australian community. I have said before, and it needs re­ peating in a debate such as this, that one cannot hope to control at the one time both the rate of growth in the money supply and the level of interest rates. We believe there is a link between the rate of growth of the money supply and the level of inflation. We are not obsessed by that link but it is a very important fundamental of our economic strategy, and we make absolutely no apology whatsoever for that. The honourable member for Gellibrand tried to take honourable members on a Cook's tour-a very selective one-to look at the performance of economies around the world. He neglected to tell the House that in growth, prospects, increases in the number of jobs and attracting investment across all sec­ tors, the Australian economy is doing far better than most others. Any objective analysis of econ­ omic conditions around the world at present would acknowledge that. One area of great concern to the Government is a too-rapid escalation of wages. A rate of growth of 1 4 per cent in average weekly earnings over the 1 2 months to the end of December is much too high. It is more than the Australian economy can afford. It diminishes the prospects for further re­ ducing the level of unemployment in Australia. [t will cost Australians jobs if it goes on unchecked and, coupled with the 35-hour week, it represents the greatest single threat to the economic recovery which on all other indicators is so clearly under way at this time. That is one of the reasons the Government is concerned to redouble its efforts to have a firm monetary policy. Of course we would like to see our money supply projection of 9 per cent to 1 1 per cent achieved, because we be­ lieve that that will make a very significant contri­ bution towards achieving the sort of economic stability and maintenance of investment levels so very important for the economic recovery now very much under way. The honourable member for Gellibrand, during his remarks, challenged me to produce some evidence of the link between controlling the money supply and the level of inflation. The best evidence is the evidence of which he is acutely aware-the evidence of the Labor years between 1 972 and 1 975 when there was absolutely no attempt to recognise that link and an absolutely irresponsible approach was taken towards allowing the money supply to ex­ pand. One of the consequences of that was an unacceptably high level of inflation. If the honourable member for Gellibrand is looking for hard evidence to establish the link, he has only to recall the experiences of that period and their consequences. I remind him again that he ought to look at some of the speeches that the now Leader of the Opposition made after he be­ came Treasurer. He ought to look at some of the speeches that the Leader of the Opposition made after he became the Leader of the Opposition. Is the honourable member for Gellibrand now ditching the Leader of the Opposition, as well as some of his other colleagues? The difference that has developed between the two of them on this subject is very interesting. The alternative Treasurer of this country has said today that there is absolutely no link between the rate of growth in the money supply and the level of inflation. He has said there is no evidence or economic theory to link the two. He ought to look very carefully at some of the speeches made by the Leader of the Opposition as far back as the time when he was Minister for Social Security in the Whitlam Government and no doubt coveting the position of Treasurer, when he quite regularly made speeches which certainly demonstrated a far more responsible approach to economic management than was being followed by the Treasurer of the time. In fact, there is a very important link be­ tween the rate of growth in the money supply and the level of inflation. The best contribution that any Government can make towards keeping interest rates down is to reduce its own borrowing demands on the Aus­ tralian financial markets. Every time an Oppo­ sition spokesman calls for more expenditure and more public sector borrowing by governments in Australia, in effect he is advocating more compe­ tition and therefore greater pressure on building societies, banks and other lending institutions to obtain funds. Apparently certain forms of press­ ure are acceptable and other forms are totally un­ acceptable. This Government has recognised from the outset that if one believes in allowing the private sector to provide the wherewithal for economic recovery, it has to be given room to move and to grow, and the demands of the public sector on the community have to be reduced. This Government shares in the regret expressed by the honourable member for Gellibrand about the present level of interest rates but one must ask what the real alternative is. The honourable member for Gellibrand would simply leave interest rates where they are; he would not have any real money supply target, he would com­ pletely dismiss any connection between the rate of growth of the money supply and the level of infla­ tion and would imagine that by following that pol­ icy somehow all would be well in the end. Of course, that is fairyland stuff. It was fairyland stuff when it was tried a few years ago and it would be fairyland stuff if it were tried again. We would be back to the levels of inflation that were experienced then. This Government has recog­ nised that the price of money is dictated by the forces of supply and demand, and to do otherwise is to be totally unrealistic and to fly the economic experience of this country Over the past few years and to fly in the face-MONICA
