Speaker: Mr STREET
Title: POLICY
text: Corangamite-Minister for Foreign Affairs) �by leave-It is now five months since I was appointed Minister for Foreign Affairs; not long enough to justify a com­ prehensive survey of Australia's foreign relations and interests, but long enough, and full enough, to justify my setting out some preliminary im­ pressions concerning the nature of this country's foreign policy and some of the more urgent tasks facing it. The first thing that is brought home very forcibly to a new Minister for Foreign Affairs is the complexity which Australia's external re­ lations have now assumed. In this respect there has been a profound change in recent years. The much tighter integration of the international com­ munity; the gradual recognition of interdepen­ dence and the emergence of institutions to man­ age it; the development of Australia itself; changes in our region-all these have moved us rapidly to the stage where Australia is now a sig­ nificant middle power with a range and depth of relations comparable to any country, other than a in the face of handful of great powers. Today our foreign policy is concerned increasingly not only with the classic issues of se­ curity and political relations, but also with trade and aid, with energy and food, with immigration and refugees, and with communications and transport. In its role as a middle power, Australia needs a foreign policy which encompasses not just bilateral relations but the multilateral diplomacy of international organisations and blocs of coun­ tries acting together. And, of course, it continues to include the day to day problems of individual people which assume even greater proportions as the personal contacts between nations rapidly increase. In a general sense, of course, this is well known, but we need to come to terms with what such a wide-ranging or total foreign policy means; what implications it carries in terms of co-ordination; the balancing of differing and sometimes compet­ ing interests, the addressing of multiple audiences, and the use of scarce human resources. Increasing complexity also makes it more important than ever to have a clear sense of Australia's national interest, defined in an enlightened and long term way, so that we can determine our priorities sensibly. I believe that it is essential to understand the needs that have to be served by the foreign policy of a middle power such as Australia. If we are to get things right in what, by general consensus, is going to be a difficult and dangerous decade, the gap between the complexity of our foreign policy, as it really is, and public perception and discussion of that policy must be narrowed. I intend to give this matter careful consider­ ation, to see what can be done on the Govern­ ment's side, to stimulate and promote discussion of the issues which face us. I have just referred to Australia as a significant middle power. This has become a familiar term of self-definition in recent years, but I do not think that we give sufficient attention to what such a status implies, what characteristics a middle power has as an actor on the world scene. The first point to make is that the designation 'middle power' refers to one's overall global pos­ ition and one's status in terms of the whole range of international issues. It does not define a nation's importance in terms of particular issues or circumstances. The 'weight' of a middle power can be very considerable indeed within its region-as ours is in South East Asia and the South West Pacific. It can be very considerable in a particular forum-as ours is in the Common­ wealth. And it can be very considerable in relation to particular resources-again, as ours is in re­ lation to food and energy. In contrast, of course, on a range of other international matters our sig­ nificance is less. This considerable variability in 'weight', depending on the issue and the circum­ stance, is one of the key characteristics of a middle power. It is one which demands very considerable judgment and flexibility in assessing situations and Australia's response to them. Closely allied to this, and again pointing to the need for sure judgment, is the fact that the bal­ ance of opportunities and constraints facing a middle power is more complicated and ambiguous than it is for either the very small or the very powerful. A middle power has more opportuni­ ties, and therefore more temptations to overreach itself, than a small power; and it faces more con­ straints, and therefore greater danger that it will be unduly cautious and timid, than a great power. Certainly the problem of striking and maintaining a proper, realistic balance between opportunity and constraint is at the core of . middle power diplomacy. Both these characteristics point to a third feature of middle power foreign policy. That quality of performance is particularly important in determining influence and status. Great powers are, almost by definition, going to be important in any event; while lack of power sets definite limits on the influence of small countries. But the variable positions of middle powers mean that how seriously they are taken and what impact they have on events in which they are involved will depend largely on the quality of human performance-on the skill, knowledge, maturity, determination and imagination of those who for­ mulate and implement their policies. Obviously this means that it is essential that the conduct of Australia's foreign policy at the pro­ fessional level be of a high standard. But it means more-much more-than that. It means that in the kind of society Australia is-the values it embodies; the degree of consen­ sus and bipartisanship that exists within it; the clarity with which its national interests are per­ ceived; the kind of leadership it enjoys; and, if I may use an old-fashioned but indispensible term, the quality of its patriotism-these things have a great bearing on the effectiveness of our foreign policy. In other words, we should not think of the term 'middle power' in fixed terms, as implying a given status which cannot be changed one way or another. The human factor is vital; it can enhance or diminish us very significantly as international actors. My fourth point is that the range of issues on which we, as a middle power, can and should COli­ centrate substantively is necessarily limited, be­ cause our resources are limited. We must be selec­ tive and resist both temptation from within and pressure from without to extend ourselves unrealistically. The issues on which we can act in this sense must be determined by our national interest and will usually be in our region or will re­ late to · special political, strategic or economic interests that we have. Having said that, however, it is important to go on to make a distinction be­ tween the scope of the substantive policies I have been discussing and the scope of what might be called declaratory policies. By declaratory policies I am referring to the ob­ ligation of a middle power to declare its position on all major issues-issues of war and peace, free­ dom and oppression, racialism, development and poverty. Australia's interests are now sufficiently wide-ranging and our status is sufficiently recog­ nised for it to be not only legitimate but also proper for us to do just that-proper because ultimately those issues can have a serious impact on us, as indeed history has repeatedly demon­ strated in this century, and proper also because, in some circumstances, a middle power can be more effective than a great power, precisely because it does not bring too much power to bear on the situ­ ation and does not automatically engage the interest of other great powers. Our intervention in the Zimbabwe conflict was a clear case in point. I believe that this is important in considering the opportunities available to a middle power: In some situations limited power is an asset rather than a liability. In making the distinction between substantive and declaratory policies, it is important to point out that it is a serious mistake to think of the first as the only ones which are real and important and of the second as merely a matter of posturing. If we have not yet learnt that words, symbols and arguments representing genuinely and strongly held views are important in international affa·irs, we have learnt very little. The history of this country has demonstrated that they are often crucial. My next observation is that for a middle power like Australia which is allied to a superpower, the management of that relationship constitutes a particularly important part of its diplomacy. The ANZUS alliance receives bipartisan support in this country and it is eminently desirable that it should continue to do so. While the alliance is reinforced by ties of friendship and cultural similarities, it is based firmly on considerations of national interest. That is not to say, of course, that Australia's national interests and those of the United States always coincide. Indeed, it would assist the management of the alliance relationship if it were appreciated that differences must exist in an alliance between powers of a very different magnitude. Far from being peculiar to the Australian-American relationship, it is entirely normal. It derives from the necessary trade-offs between the desire to maximise the benefits of co­ operation and shared interests on the one hand, and the concern to safeguard independence of action on the other. We should neither deny the existence of these differences nor engage in para­ noid exaggeration concerning them. We should rather accept them as a part of life and work out our policies accordingly, appreciating as we do that our superpower ally is a free, democratic and pluralistic country. Quite clearly the development of this middle power concept is closely linked to the practical formulation of foreign policy. I turn now to some of the issues which are cur­ rently in the forefront of Australian foreign pol­ icy. In doing so I shall not try to be comprehensive but shall focus on those aspects which my pattern of visits to date has highlighted. The first one is Kampuchea. In the last five months I have had the oportunity of discussing this question in four member countries of the Association of South East Asian Nations, as well as in Tokyo, Peking and Washington. That is, I have discussed it in every like-minded country, apart from New Zealand and Singapore, that has a serious interest in the maintenance of peace and stability in South East Asia. Naturally, I will be looking to discuss the issue of Kampuchea with those two countries at the earliest opportunity. During my recent visit to the United States I also had the opportunity to have a very useful discussion on Kampuchea with the United Nations Secretary-General, Dr Waldheim. Australia regards the implementation of the United Nations Resolution on Kampuchea as essential for the restoration of peace in the region. I want to stress that on the basic issues involved in Kampuchea, our interests coincide with the countries I have mentioned. There should be no misunderstanding about this, either in Australia or outside it, or about the meaning of our derecog­ nition last month of the so-called Government of Democratic Kampuchea. That act of derecogni­ tion was based on two considerations, one moral and one practical. Morally, the regime in question was so repugnant that we felt that continuing rec­ ognition was unjustifiable; practically, as long as the question of recognition remained unsettled it would confuse and distract attention from the basic strategic and political questions at issue. Powerful as these considerations were, the bal­ ance of arguments was not clear cut. Against them, the Government had to weigh the opinions and interests of the other countries in the region which share our basic interests. Some of them are much closer to the sharp end than we are and have had to bear a much greater burden as the re­ sult of what has happened to Kampuchea. This affected the timing of our act of derecognition. The Government makes no apology for this but I want to make it clear beyond any doubt and ambi­ guity that our opposition to Vietnam's invasion of Kampuchea remains implacable. We reject outright that that invasion proceeded on the basis of a concern for the welfare of the Khmer people. We reject outright the claim that the Heng Samrin regime, which the invasion installed, is the legitimate representative of the Khmer people. We deplore and oppose the continued Vietnamese occupation of Kampuchea because it denies the independence of the Khmer people, because it affects the security of Thailand and other Asian countries, because it holds the threat of Vietnamese hegemony in the region and because it imports a Soviet strategic presence into the re­ gion. In this last respect, I draw attention not only to the significant strategic presence which the Soviet Union has now achieved in Indo-China, but to the fact that Vietnam launched its invasion of Kampuchea only after it had signed a so-called treaty of friendship and co-operation with the Soviet Union. It was this which gave it the secur­ ity guarantee against China which was a condition for its attack. We deeply regret Vietnam's refusal to accom­ modate the legitimate interests and concerns of its neighbours and to play a more constructive and co-operative role in the region. In the end Viet­ nam itself will be the greatest loser as a result of its actions, in terms of isolation internationally and from its neighbours, and of domestic economic difficulties and social strains, which have been identified as causes for serious concern by the Vietnamese authorities themselves. Australia will continue to support actively the interests of the ASEAN countries in restoring stability to the re­ gion and the implementation of the United Nations resolution on Kampuchea. With respect to the region, we want nothing but the restoration of peace and stability, the conditions which will allow its prosperity to grow-but we are serious in wanting that. We will watch carefully the efforts to create a new political grouping of Khmers­ what is sometimes referred to as a 'third force'­ and will naturally review our position if the situ­ ation changes significantly. In January I visited two great Asian powers situated further to the north-Japan and China. I was pleased to have confirmed that with both of these ancient and formidable nations Australia has been able to establish a sound relationship, based in both cases on mutual economic advan­ tage, goodwill, and a degree of common percep­ tion of the international scene. With Japan, of course, we have more in common-in terms of similar democratic and free enterprise insti� tutions, of our relations with the United States, and the way we view events on the mainland of Asia. China is a participant in those events, and a most important one. Our interests and China's are not always the same, but as I said we have many perceptions in common-concern about Soviet policies and intentions, for example, and a wish to see stability in East Asia. Honourable members will be aware of recent reports of the results of the re-examination of economic policies and priorities that has been going on in China and the restraints which have resulted from this. As far as Australia's own com­ mercial interests in China are concerned, the pol­ icy of restraint could well lead to a reduction in demand for some commodities supplied from Australia, but these reductions seem likely to be limited, and Chinese interest in economic and technological co-operation with Australia re­ mains high. It is not an easy task for China's leaders to maintain a steady policy course, given the scale of the problems they face and the awakened aspir­ ations of their people for a better and more pre­ dictable life. However, after the convulsions and distortions of the Cultural Revolution, more prag­ matic leaders, who seek to meet these aspirations, have emerged. China's present leaders now look back with bitterness at the years of the Cultural Revolution and its wasted efforts. Vice-Chairman Deng Xiaoping told me in January that it would take longer to undo the harmful effects of the Cul­ tural Revolution than it had to cause them. De­ spite this, Chinese leaders were resolute in saying that they were facing up to the task of rehabili­ tation, were conscious of the demands of their people, and that broad policy lines would not change. I found these statements welcome. I be­ lieve that it is in our broad political and strategic interest, as well as in our bilateral commercial interest, that China maintain its outward-looking orientation and 'Window to the West'. When I refer to strategic interests, I have in mind the glo­ bal balance, the Asia-Pacific area, and North Asia in particular, where four great powers-China, Japan, the Soviet Union and the United States­ are all involved, and where China's favourable disposition is of considerable importance. I turn now to the question of our relationship with the United States under the new Administra­ tion. Recently, as honourable members will know, I have had the opportunity of speaking to several of the key foreign policy and national security members of the Administration, including Vice­ President Bush, Secretaries Haig and Weinberger and Ambassador Kirkpatrick. The first point I should make is that I gained a clear impression from my private discussions that what these im­ portant members of the Administration have been saying in public is not merely rhetoric for its own sake. They mean what they say, they believe that important changes are required in American foreign policy, and they will not easily be deflected from their course. The Administration is proceeding in a very deliberate way and I believe that the end result of the series of comprehensive policy reviews now in train will be a greater de­ gree of predictability in the content and conduct of American foreign policy. This is a development which Australia, for its part, will welcome. Secondly, I was struck by the extent to which the philosophical perspectives and the analysis of the international situation of the Reagan A d m in is t r at i o n and of the Australian Government-as set out in a series of statements over the last five years-coincide. I refer particu­ larly to a shared concern about the grave impli­ cations of the remorseless military build-up by the Soviet Union; about the need to maintain a mili­ tary balance as a condition for stability and effec­ tive negotiations; about the need to improve con­ sultation and co-ordination within the Western Alliance; about the need for purposeful American leadership; and about the need to pay close atten­ tion to crisis situations outside the West itself. Thirdly, I was left with the very firm impression that the attitude of the new Administration to military power is not-I repeat not-that there should be early recourse to it in order to settle dis­ putes. On the contrary, it is that the possession of adequate power is desirable precisely because it reduces the chances of armed conflict. It is be­ lieved, and the Australian Government shares this belief, that it is uncertainty, vacillation, disunity and weakness which increase the prospect of war by inviting expansionist, aggressive behaviour by states seeking to change the balance of power to their own advantage. Preparedness and evident resolution diminish the prospect of war. I stress this point because, either inadvertently or deliberately, it is often misrepresented. There are always some who, �hile they find it possible to re­ main silent in the face of huge military efforts on the part of the Soviet Union, raise the cry of war­ mongering whenever the West shows any sign of matching that effort. Fourthly, the new Administration believes that the various elements of foreign policy-economic matters, human rights, strategic and political questions-cannot be treated as separate and dis­ tinct but that they must all be seen as components of the whole. This may be the most valid meaning of that much used concept 'linkage'. Currently, this is particularly relevant to the way in which the issues at stake in Central America are viewed. For our part, the Australian Government believes that human rights issues are of the greatest im­ portance. But we also believe it wrong to assume that economic reform issues and human rights can be divorced from questions of security and strat­ egy. That distinction does not serve the cause of strengthening these rights. There are precious few human rights in the Soviet Union and Cuba, and in the regimes they support and install. Lastly, the fact that there is broad agreement between the Australian Government and the Reagan Administration on the analysis and evalu­ ation of international affairs, should not be taken as implying that there will be automatic or across­ the-board agreement between us. The very nature of international politics means we shan have our differences. Our perspectives as a regional power, as a developed country with almost exclusively Third World neighbours, and as a member of a multi-racial Commonwealth will necessarily differ from those of a global superpower on occasions. As an ally of the United States we will continue to pursue as helpful and co-operative a role as possible in the responses of the United States and the West generally to particular situ­ ations as they emerge. At the same time, however, Australia will seek to make its contribution on the basis of an independent national judgment, as is currently the case in the Indian Ocean. Equally important, Australian assistance can only be on the basis of complete consistency with Australia's national interests and the maintenance of our national sovereignty. I believe that these realities are well understood and accepted in Washington. The fourth and last issueor complex of issues-that I want to touch on is that of North­ South relations. This is an area where Australia, as a middle power and an active and important trading nation, can play a role. Among developed countries Australia has distinctive interests. They derive from OUf geographical position and the re­ gional concerns flowing from it, as well as some features of our own economy. But there are also vital global interests to be served in efforts to re­ solve North-South issues. This Government is deeply committed to the view that the peace and stability of the world between now and the end of this century will depend to a very considerable extent on progress towards easing the tensions be­ tween developed and developing countries. Efforts must be made to assist the developing world to solve its problems. Only those with an interest in instability and conflict will benefit if progress is not made. Promoting the evolution of a better and more equitable international economic order also holds out the prospect of benefits for both North and South. Assisting the South to realise its full poten­ tial will provide significant economic opportuni­ ties for the North. It has to be recognised that in some important respects, this year is not pro­ pitious for North-South dialogue. There are increasing pressures on scarce budget resources and trends towards restriction of trading oppor­ tunities which made progress more difficult. The combination of serious economic difficulties in developing countries, including continuing infla­ tion and reduced growth rates, with increased East-West tension centred on Afghanistan, Poland and El Salvador, has distracted attention from North-South issues and created an un­ favourable climate. Impatience and cynicism feed off each other. The Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting which is to be held in Melbourne in Sep­ tember will provide a unique opportunity this year for leaders from both North and South to transform the dialogue over North-South issues into practical measures. At the last Common­ wealth Heads of Government Meeting in Lusaka, two years ago, those present succeeded in resolv­ ing the problem of Zimbabwe. Until then it had defeated all efforts at solution. In the same way I hope that at Melbourne the leaders of the Com­ monwealth will succeed in making that meeting a significant landmark with respect to North-South issues. We should certainly aim for such a result. We would want to see such progress translated into effective and sustainable practical programs which would help to mobilise national and inter­ national efforts in the development task. Return­ ing to the point which I stressed earlier, it may be that a determined initiative by a number of middle powers has a better chance of getting things moving in present circumstances. Certainly Australia, as host, will try to give a resolute lead that direction. Mr Deputy Speaker, in concluding what has been in the nature of an interim report to Parlia­ ment, I would like to say that in the visits I have so far paid to heads of government and Foreign Min­ isters I have been very struck by the regard and re­ spect paid to Australia. I think the point is worth making because, while we have in the past oc­ casionally exaggerated our importance in the world, more often we are inclined to indulge our Australian gift for scepticism and deflation by insisting on our comparative insignificance. This is not only self-damaging, it is plain wrong. We are, as I have been at pains to emphasise, a significant middle power. There is an important role for us to play in our region, in the Western alliance, in the Commonwealth, in the United Nations and in the North-South dialogue. We must have the will to respond to the challenge, and the determination to make the most of our opportunities. I present the following paper: Foreign Policy-Ministerial Statement, 24 March 198 1 . Motion (by Mr Hodgman) proposed: That the House take note of the paper. Motion (by Mr Hodgman)-by leave-agreed to: That so much of the Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent the Deputy Leader of the Opposition speaking for a period not exceeding 27 minutes.

Speaker: Mr LIONEL BOWEN
Title: POLICY
text: Kingsford-Smith) (4.57)-We have heard an interim report, as the Minister for Foreign Affairs ( Mr Street) de­ scribed it, covering his five months in office. He has paid considerable attention to the fact that we now define ourselves a middle power. In fact, some eight pages of the speech is devoted to defi­ ning a middle power. He has also raised the ques­ tion of Australia being an actor on the world stage. The problem with that sort of reference, of course, is that actors often fail. Their words might be effective, but their performance might be very limited indeed. I think the most significant part of what the Minister has said is that we have our own national interests to look after, and that we have consider­ able weight in S outh East Asia . Having highlighted those words, I want to make the point in my submission that the Government has not acted in accordance with its words. It was about page 1 4 of the speech before the Minister referred to the new Reagan Administration. J want to deal with it from the beginning. The Foreign Minister spoke of the policies of the Reagan Administration. He does not seem to understand that our ally has a vastly different set in of policies now from what it had four months ago. These drastic changes in the way that Washington sees the world have the most serious implications for Australia. It is amazing to note that, as the Minister has now said, there is broad agreement between the Australian Government and the Reagan Administration on the analysis �nd the evaluation of international affairs. There was ap­ parently broad agreement between this Govern­ ment and the Carter Administration a mere five months ago. The inevitable conclusion is that since American policies have changed so drasti­ cally in the short intervening period we do not have an independent foreign policy but an imitat­ ive and subservient one. A deadly serious choice is facing us. Will we use our influence to counsel moderation, to urge a new search for easing inter­ national tensions-detente or the Strategic Arms Limitation Treaty was not mentioned in any part of the Minister's speech-or will we, as this Government is doing, take actions and enter into agreements which will encourage i ncreased mis­ trust between the super-powers and trigger a new and criminally expensive arms race ultimately operating against our interests by increasing in­ stability in this region of the world? It is becomiflg apparent that if a major international disaster is to be averted middle powers such as Australia must play an increasingly important role. Australia's importance has increased substantially in the past five years largely because of its resources. It will increase even more in the next decade. The American alliance is important, but it is not, and cannot be, a substitute or an excuse for a vigorous policy of independently assessing our own interests. Super-powers such as the United States and the Soviet Union tend to export insta­ bility and resolve their conflicting interests in places remote from their own territories; for example, in Africa, the Middle East, the Gulf, and in South East Asia. We are still living with the very real problems of Vietnam and Kampuchea. Kampuchea was the first matter mentioned by the Minister. Those problems still affect the United States but pose more ominous problems for the countries of this region, not the least of which is Australia. The United States, like every great power, will put its interests first. Anyone who thinks other­ wise has a simplistic and naive view of the inter­ national arena. It is we who must worry most about the stability of our region. The easy answer-to leave our powerful ally to call the strategic shots-unfortunately is clearly the wrong answer. We already have a number of United States bases in Australia, a subject which I will canvass at some later time. We are contributing substan­ tially to the ANZUS alliance. Do we really be­ lieve that the staging of nuclear weapons through­ out Australia, the contingency against which the B52 agreement has been entered into, will con­ tribute to stability in our part of the world? It will not. If anything, it will encourage the Soviet Union to escalate its involvement with Vietnam to counter that perceived threat. It will decrease respect · among our regional neighbours for our independence of judgment and, consequently, it will lessen the respect with which our · voice is heard in regional councils. It will be a major con­ tribution to escalating a new cold war between the super-powers and in our region · provoking increased instability. When · I com�enced my speech I said that United States policies have fundamentally changed. The Minister for Foreign Affairs should realise that the United States strategic world view has fundamentally changed. For the past four months we have witnessed the most dramatic changes in American attitudes, not only in the rhetoric of General Haig but also in the American activities around the world. There emerge� II clear pattern : Intervention in EI Salvador to prop up a government which, according to the testimony of the United States Ambassador, an experienced and professional man, had slaughtered thousands of its own people; increased armaments and mili­ tary assistance to the Middle East and to the Gulf; an amount of $600m committed in additional arms supplies to Saudi Arabia; additional military aid for. Egypt and Israel; a mooted decision to supply .arms directly to Afghanistan; increased support for South Africa and its repugnant poli­ cies; the establishment of new American bases and the enlargement of old ones in the Horn of Afriqa, in the Gulf and in the Indian Ocean; dra­ matically increased support for the military dic­ tatorships and juntas of Latin America; a return to the Cold War rhetoric of the 1 950s in relation to the Soviet Union; and, finally, the establish­ ment of staging facilities for long range strategic nuclear bombers in Australia. All these events make it absolutely clear that the United States is determined to increase its power in every region of the world. But are these increases hi Australia's interests ? Perhaps it would be comforting to believe that the United States fights for peace, justice and human rights and that the Soviet Union is an unprincipled ag­ gressor. That the latter is true in the case of Afghanistan unfortunately does not make the former proposition tenable. We have witnessed in Washington unprincipled and transparent policy reversals which scrap human rights as an instru­ ment of foreign policy and substitute supposedly an all-out attack on terrorism. The problem we face is that General Haig includes amongst those he calls 'terrorists' patriots who oppose dictatorial governments-governments that the United States supports because they further its own interests and strategic designs. Let me be more specific. Washington supports dictatorships or military juntas in South Korea, Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia and a score of other countries. It is providing them with increased military assist­ ance and weapons which will be used to crush any dissident opinion, or those who attempt to establish a democracy. But Washington encour­ ages or is about to encourage terrorist activities against such internationally recognised govern­ ments as that of Angola because that Government is socialist or Marxist or perhaps just because it is not in an American alliance. The Australian Labor Party has never held and will not hold any brief for the Soviet Union. We deplore its abuses of human rights and its invasion of weaker countries. We equally deplore any simple-minded attachment to the United States as the paragon of virtue. Our foreign policy has to be based on a realistic appraisal of the faults of both countries and on a willingness to break ranks with the United States when it acts in a way which fos­ ters instability in Asia and the Pacific. The Foreign Minister has implied quite clearly that we should trust Washington. But we must learn from the lessons of recent history how governments in Washington behave, how they pursue their own interests, and how they have made tragic mis­ takes. It is quite wrong for us to be always follow­ ing the United States ship, no matter who its cap­ tain is or what course it takes. Will the Americans really come to our aid in the time of a crunch? I wish to place this matter in perspective. In the early 1 960s the then Australian Foreign Minister, Mr Barwick, returned from Washington and an­ nounced that the United States would support us if we were attacked by the Indonesians. Those were the days of confrontation between Indonesia and Malaysia. Subsequently, it emerged that Mr Barwick had received a secret assurance to this effect from the American Secretary of State, Dean Rusk a secret assurance which was lodged in the safe in the Embassy in Washington. Some time later President Kennedy became aware of the agreement and he countermanded his Sec­ retary of State and made it clear that the Americans would not feel bound by the ANZUS Treaty to come to our aid in such an event. This incident gives cause for a long and careful pause because the ANZUS alliance does not com­ mit anybody to active involvement in anything other than through consultation. Perhaps we should reflect also upon the fact that when Presi­ dent Nixon and Secretary of State Kissinger de­ cided to bomb Cambodia they did not even inform their own Cabinet. Is it any wonder that the American people so revolted against those people who so deceived their own nation that they were thrown out of office? Their policies operated throughout South East Asia and certainly brought about the undoing of Sihanouk in Kampuchea. The Foreign Minister is naive, and dangerously so, if he is asking this Parliament to base our foreign policy on implicitly trusting the American leaders as they change from time to time. Within the last few weeks Washington has offered $ 1 5 billion in additional weapons and mili­ tary aid to Latin America, Europe, the Middle East, Africa and Asia. The tremendous danger is that the new Administration in Washington is attempting to impose military solutions on every type of regional problem. United States defence spending next year will be 30 per cent of Federal spending. We have to look at what is happening in the United States. Is not the best defence the wel­ fare of one's own people? In its same Budget the United States has slashed the concessions to the victims of black lung disease-the miners, by $378m. That is where there is a lack of balance and understanding. One can well lose the defence of one's country by a malaise from within. We want to be able to say to new Administrations in the United States: 'Do not forsake diplomacy. Do not forswear subtlety for a simplistic and militar­ istic approach'. The present policies of the United States smack of not only excessive simplicity but also ill-considered haste. We are concurring in­ stead of vigorously urging policies which will not create further instability in our part of the world. But the West Germans did not do that. Last week the West German Foreign Minister urged Gen­ eral Haig not to become so obsessed with the mili­ tary build up that he neglected arms control. We have not made any such representations and we should do so. We are in the process of becoming a major power " in South East Asia-we already are a major power in the South Pacificbut we have not taken any initiatives commensurate with our status and regional responsibilities. No one pre­ tends that the problems in Vietnam and Kam­ puchea have easy solutions. But if we moved to re­ establish our program of aid to Vietnam we would have some influence and capacity for initiative in that area. In order to retain our capacity for in­ itiative we must preserve a substantial degree of independence. If we lock ourselves in completely with the United States of America strategic view of the world-if we become, as we are in danger of becoming, a South Pacific outpost for Washington-we cannot expect to be taken seriously by our regional neighbours. It is about time we formulated our own strategic view and acted accordingly. In the Middle East the United States Govern­ ment has now promised another $600m in arma­ ments for Saudi Arabia. Naturally, that worries Tel Aviv, so another $600m in military aid is given to Israel. That, in turn, worries Sadat in Egypt, so another $ 1 .65 billion in 'security assistance' is given to Egypt. What a recipe for regional insta­ bility! General Haig has even indicated that he plans to ov'er-arm Israel to deter future adventures by Libya, Syria or other radical Arabs. Is that not a recipe for disaster? No doubt the American economy will improve as the world's biggest arms factories gear up to full international conflict level. Given the way in which Washing­ ton works and the power of the armaments lobby there, we develop a healthy cynicism about cur­ rent United States policy. One of President Reagan's aides admitted this last week: So far the perception we've created is one of willy-nilly shovelling arms all over the world. How true, but how tragic. The Minister in his speech referred to this belief of the Reagan Administration: . . . that the various elements of foreign policy­ economil4,matters, human rights, strategic and political ques­ tions ,, ' . . must all be seen as components of the whole. He continued: There are precious few human rights in the Soviet Union and Cuba, and in the regimes they support and install. We could say: 'True, but what about China, South America and a number of other areas'. His sum­ mary would have been much more impressive and balanced had he pointed out that there are precious few human rights under most of the regimes which the United States supports-as I said, particularly those in Latin America and Asia. A close examination of the report of the Human Rights Commission in Geneva will reveal that of the many countries which systematically practise torture, the majority are supported by the new American Administration. The fact is that the military dictatorship has be­ come the dominant form of government in those sectors of the Third World which are geographi­ cally and politically closest to the United States. It cannot last. Why is it that a government has to get arms to suppress its people? How can that poss­ ibly last when the only solution for those people is to turn to communism and revolution, which has always been the solution, without any regard for human rights and democratic rights? It is most disturbing that the Minister said: It has to be recognised that in some important respects year is not propitious for the North-South dialogue. We hear that from the wealthy countries every year. No year will ever be propitious. Meanwhile, millions of people will starve. The Australian Labor Party has always had policies which relate to humanity and human rights. Ours is a party of concern. This Govern­ ment should not delay any longer making a generous response to the needs of the poorest countries. This Government's performance in providing assistance to the developing world is now at the lowest level it has ever been, This Government is not moving towards meeting the assistance target of 0.7 per cent of gross national product set by the United Nations; it is moving away from it. Its allocation is now down to 0.4 per cent of GNP. The level was highest under the Labor Government. I agree with the Minister in his statement that it is essential that: . . , the conduct of Australia's foreign policy at the pro­ fessional level be of a high standard, But what are the facts? I believe our professional officers are doing their best, but the Government's policies in those areas have led to more than 50 of our career officers recently resigning or transfer­ ring. That is a development which has weakened our ability even to conduct a foreign policy of a high standard. Perhaps for the most glaring example of this weakness we should return to the situation in Washington. In spite of the Jact that we have there a number of diplomatic officers, and 200 representatives of the Department of De­ fence and of the armed Services, there is not one person reporting, on a regular basis, changes in the strategic policies of our American allies, It is those policies that determine whether we get in­ volved in a war, yet we have nobody there report­ ing from that very source. The Foreign Minister devoted a substantial part of his speech to the issue of Kampuchea. I have been to the Kampuchea border. [ have also been to Vietnam and to Thailand and I have been in the camps catering for the unfortunate ref­ ugees. What I want to say now is based on that sort of knowledge. There are glaring omissions in the Minister's analysis. He does not recognise the issues at the heart of the Kampuchean problem, namely, firstly, the attempts by the Pol Pot regime between 1 975 and 1 978 to destroy its own people; and secondly, the rescue of the survivors of the Khmer people by Vietnam. The Minister de­ scribed the Pol Pot regime as morally repugnant. That is mild language indeed for a regime which, in a genocidal fury, slaughtered or starved to death more than three million of its own people. I invite the Minister to go to the refugee camps of this the Khmers and ask them who they fear the most. He will find that it is Pol Pot. The Minister did not spell out the horrifying statistics of the Kam­ puchean tragedy. Further, he made no apology for the continued recognition of the Pol Pot regime long after it had been driven from power and long after its massive crimes had been revealed to a shocked world. The Minister claimed that the balance of arguments for derecognition of Pol Pot was not clear cut. How much more appalling does international behav­ iour have to be to make a recognition issue clear" cut? Again, the Minister said that the Govermnent's opposition to Vietnam's invasion of Kampuchea was implacable. That is a strong word. It is unqualified by any recognition that the inter7 vention of Vietnam saved the survivors of the Kampuchean people. Is Vietnam to get no credit or even recognition of that fact? Further, the Minister rejected any suggestion-and it was not one made by Labor-that the Heng Samrin Administration represented the Khmer people. The Heng Samrin Administration has struggled to get Kampuchea back on the road to recovery. It gets no credit from the Minister yet his Govern­ ment recognised as the legitimate representative of the Khmer people an exiled junta of genocidal fanatics. This points up the contradiction in the Minister's speech and it makes his analysis pitiful indeed. Having finally steeled itself to withdraw Aus­ tralian diplomatic support from the Pol Pot regime, the Government has taken no steps towards a settlement, ' towards a solution in Indo China. Of course, Labor has long advocated derecognition. What the Government has fol­ lowed is Labor's policy, and I suggest that it now follow another Labor policy. Labor advocates an independent Australian initiative. We shOUld aim as our highest diplomatic priority in Asia to ar­ range a regional conference on the Indo-China issue as a forerunner of a larger conference which would have to include the United States, the Soviet Union and China. Australia should strive to play the part of the honest broker in this issue. That is not beyond the capacity of a middle power as the Minister correctly describes Australia. Ac­ cordingly, we should be setting about persuading the Association of South East Asian Nations states and Vietnam to confer on the Kampuchean issue. Such a conference could aim at the with­ drawal of the Vietnamese, linked to cast iron guarantees that the Pol Pot forces would also' be disarmed and prevented from rushing back into the vacuum created. The conference should aim also at a genuine act of self-determination within Kampuchea. The Minister mentioned the possibility of a Thin! Force emerging in the affairs of Kam­ puchea. But the history of Indo-china since 1 945 shows that the Third Force idea is rriainly wishful thinking. It failed in Vietnam and in Laos. In Kampuchea itself the United States destroyed the neutrality of Kampuchea under Prince Sihanouk. The Minister rightly pointed to the risk of inter­ national isolation of Vietnam but he suggested nothi!1g to prevent it. Australia itself is at fault in helping to force Vietnam into isolation. Our petty and thoughtless action in cutting off our aid to Vietnam in 1 979 is not, of course, to be compared with the ruthless breaking of United States prom­ ises of post-war aid to Vietnam. Overall, the Minister's remarks on Kampuchea are marked by double standards and a lack of compassion. In the case of Vietnam, we can detect the lingering animosity of a member of a party which saw its policies on Vietnam totally discredited, totally defeated, totally humiliated, and which towards the end of that war, helped lead his party to political defeat. The offensive in Vietnam was to stop the downward thrust of China, the new found ally of this Government. That is the point. This Government bears towards Vietnam an obvious animosity, but rancour is no basis for foreign policy. Not one Minister of this Government has ever visited . Hanoi. A lame duck ambassador is in Hanoi because of the Government's attitude towards Vietnam. The;; Government ought to re­ member that people'are entitled to aid. If there is another thrust by China against Vietnam, Australia will receive millions of refugees. Where is the substance of the Government's policy in that event? Where is the influence that will stop trat happening?' It will not be solved by B52 bombers because the Government has already dealt with them. We have to make it clear that Vietnam is the most important power in South East Asia. Our neighbours in ASEAN will agree with that.'What is the 'Government's policy? It is so short-sighted and so mean-spirited that it is contrary to Australia's best interests. The Aus­ tralian people will remember that the parties which comprise this Government took a gener­ ation to recognise the realities of China-indeed, to recognise it at all. ' Fortunately, our national interests will not have to wait that long again to be properly protected by realistic and constructive policies towards Vietnam. The next Labor government will treat relations with Vietnam with the importance and urgency they deserve.

Speaker: Mr HODGMAN
Title: POLICY
text: It will be a long time off.

Speaker: Mr LIONEL BOWEN
Title: POLICY
text: It will not be a long time off because the issues are very close to our shores. If the Government thinks it can solve the problems by pitting bombers against flesh and blood it is gravely mistaken. The Vietnamese fought for 30 years against the French and every­ body else, and the Government ought to realise that. Specifically, the Minister's speech raised the prospect of Australia, as a middle power, having an independent foreign policy but it did not follow through with any initiatives. It is on that basis that I make the point that it is about time Australia de­ veloped independent foreign policies which will bring peace and stability into the South East Asian region. It has to exercise its own initiative. It should not leave it to somebody else. This Government has to pursue initiatives that are in accordance with Australia's interests and Australian public opinion. By so doing we will be­ come a better ally to the United States. We will lessen the burden that the Haigs and others want to impose on the American people by the stupid suggestion that the way to peace is through war and that the way to detente is through an escala­ tion of arms. It is a fallacy. It will not work. The American people will reject it before long. It is about time a government in this region stood up and stated: 'We are an ally but because we live in this region we have views which are much more fundamentally orientated to the truth and to the valid claims of the region than those of any high­ powered general or somebody who espouses the cause of democracy in the world when it is failing so fast'. What a tragedy it is that all the wars fought in South Korea or Vietnam have done ' notliirig but bring about dictatorships and com­ munism. They have failed at every level. If people are not granted human rights and a chance to de­ velop their capacity to run their own countries totalitarian regimes are created. It is about time General Haig and others started talking again, as Carter did, about human rights and democracy and about giving aid when promised. Honourable members opposite should not groan. They are young enough to have been involved in those conflicts. What about the 450 Australian dead left in Vietnam? The Govern­ ment should face up to these issues, as have the Australian people. The Government was hounded out of office because of its failure in this area. Today we heard a speech that still puts us in the position of regarding Vietnam as the enemy. That can be a danger, as I have said, if there is a war between China and Vietnam. It is our clear­ cut responsibility as a nation in this region to get Vietnam and ASEAN together to talk about Viet­ nam's withdrawal from Kampuchea once Pol Pot and his regime are disarmed. Those talks should not be held on any other level. Until such time as we organise that conference-we should be ini­ tiating it-we will have nothing but instability in this region.

Speaker: Mr SHIPTON
Title: POLICY
text: Higgins) (5.24)-1 congratu­ late the Minister for Foreign Affairs ( Mr Street) on the survey of Australia's foreign relations which he presented to the Parliament today. Of particular significance is his assessment of the new Reagan Administration in the United States. He said that the philosophical perspectives and the analysis of the international situation of that new Administration are similar to the policies of the Australian Government over a longer period. Speaker: Mr BEAZLEY
Title: POLICY
text: Swan) (5.40)-I wish to make a couple of points on the speech of the honourable member for Higgins ( Mr Shipton) before passing to the remarks of the Minister for Foreign Affairs ( Mr Street). Firstly, the honourable member disputed the view expressed by the Deputy specifically Leader of the Opposition ( Mr Lionel Bowen) that Australia is now a staging point for the deploy­ ment of American nuclear weapons. I do not see why we have to keep disputing this; we indisputa­ bly are. Most of the American warships which visit my home town and home port of Fremantle carry nuclear weapons. The agreement which was entered by the Government on the use by B52s Australian bases does not preclude the possibility that at some point in time B52s passing through Australia might well be armed with nuclear weapons. We have at North West Cape a facility which is responsible for transmitting fire orders to American ballistic missile submarines. All these facts are well known and well documented from American official sources. Some are attested to by and is the Government itself. We need a far more mature approach than has been displayed by the honourable member to the problems that we con­ front in our relationship with the American stra­ along'. That tegic nuclear deterrent. My second point concerns Vietnam. From 1975 onwards the Opposition made persistent pleas to this Government that if it did not take seriously the moral obligations imposed upon it to provide assistance for the reconstruction of Vietnam that in country would be forced to fall back upon the Soviet Union. We pointed to the difficulties that would occur because of the pressures that would be placed upon the Vietnamese administration by the Soviet Union to allow it the use of the Cam Ranh Bay facilities, with the Vietnamese being forced to succumb if they were not provided with the sorts of material assistance they required for it is economic recovery. We have persistently warned the Government about that and have said that such steps would be against Australia's interests. We have persistently attempted to get the Government to do something about it. Just as per­ sistently, the Government has done nothing. It is now reaping the consequences of not using the pressure that Australia could undoubtedly place on the United States, or the friendly influence or persuasion in which it could indulge with that country, to persuade it to adopt a similar policy. the We are now confronted by the consequences of that failure. The Minister's statement is extremely general, follows a visit by him to the United States dur­ ing which agreements of a specific military nature were entered into. Such discussions must have been based on quite specific understandings about the nature of future directions of American policy and our views on our association with it. Yet none of that appears in this statement-at least not associated with the agreements into which Australia entered. The Minister has dealt with the question of the distribution of power in north-east Asia without giving us the benefit of the Government's views on disputes within the new American Administration on a one-China policy or a two-Chinas policy which, despite former President Ford's visit to China, have not of been resolved. Did the Minister express to the United States a view on proposed arms sales to Taiwan? If not, why not? If so, what did he say; why did he not present the details to the Parlia­ ment in the course of his rather lengthy analysis of our relationship with China? The Minister visited the United States at a time when President Reagan had signalled a shift in United States policy towards South Africa, one potentially of considerable embarrassment to our Government; yet he has given no indication that he exchanged opinions on the matter with the officials he met. The Minister spoke of a commit­ ment to American objectives in the Indian Ocean, without expressing views On whether features of the burgeoning military involvement of the United States in that area, and the massive arms sales to such states as Saudi Arabia, are appropri­ ate meanS of responding to the problems that we confront in that region. An unexceptionable analysis of the requirements of a middle power such as Australia's to assume an appropriate role in world affairs was followed by apparently unrelated, but unequivocal applause for the direc­ tion of the policy of our major ally. This does not really reflect an adequate level of systematic thinking by the Minister on the problems which Australia confronts. There has been in government ranks some evi­ dence that the Government wishes to leap into the type of relationship that Australia had with its major ally in the 1 960s. To some extent the Minis­ ter's statement reflected that view. Probably at no time since the 1 960s has it been more important that this nation's leaders take full adv;mtage of the critical possibilities that years of friendship with the United States permit a country like Australia. It would be wrong to claim substantial influence but ours would probably be more than other powers of an equivalent size, and we are located on the outskirts of regions where the United States is more in need of good advice than anywhere else on the globe. In the past year the Government has viewed, with a degree of relish, the elevation of military strategic issues to the forefront of international lations and the possibilities for deepening global ideological conflict. In the process it has failed to recognise the extent to which these cut across other international interests which it and we on this side of the House have upheld. The Govern­ ment endangers a consensus on a sound defence strategy for Australia. It ignores the very real interest that aspects of our relationships with the United States now give us in the sanity and re­ straint of both super-powers. American facilities in this country give us a very real interest in en­ couraging caution and stability in the Kremlin as well as in Washington. The United States is on the verge of committing some serious mistakes in our vicinity-mistakes which this Government recognises but which, if it persists in its current course, it will be powerless to prevent. On the whole, the Government has maintained and nurtured important links with the Third WorId which were established by the Whitlam Government. It has been committed to this out of principle and a sensible appreciation of the realities of political life in our neighbourhood. These are threatened by some contemporary de­ velopments in United States policy. The Reagan Administration in a number of key policy areas foreshadows moves at variance with our stand. They are moves which with increasing ideological confrontation are inevitable. Perhaps nothing exemplifies them better than the embarrassment this Government will experience in respect of its policy toward South Africa. It is quite evident that President Reagan intends to rehabilitate the South African regime. It is all very well to point out, as the Prime Minister ( Mr Malcolm Fraser) did in answer to a question of mine, that the Reagan Administration opposes apartheid. The point is that instead of that being the fundamental feature of United States-South African policy it is now being shifted to the status of a minor snag-a matter we raise with the South Africans but be­ cause of their alleged importance we go no further as we deepen our relationship by grounding it on a mutual security interest. That is a strategy this Government must oppose if it values consistency and its standing in our ,·egion. President Reagan expressed his views publicly on the matter while the Foreign Minister was in the United States but there is no record in his statement of his having raised the matter with the President or any of his advisers. As we have matured over the last decade, im­ perceptibly Australia and the United States have come to play on different chess boards in the in­ ternational arena. That appropriate to a super­ power is one where every regional issue is seen in a re­ global context, and that which is appropriate to a regional power-ourselves-is where we ought to see every regional issue in terms related to the local situation on the ground, that is, isslles of local significance. Our standing in the Common­ wealth is very high as is our standing with a var­ iety of nations in the Indian Ocean-Western Pacific regions. That standing has bceome more important to us than evcr it was in the 1 960s. There is a price, however, for its main tenance and that is our independence, our willingness to ident­ ify with ideological positions and economic priori­ ties which will cut across mili tary-political imperatives in our strategic relations with the United States. The United States at the same time has established a complicated adversary relation­ ship with the Soviet Union which requires a ca­ pacity to respond flexibly to Soviet initiatives, to raise and lower tensions over relatively short periods. It is something which the United States can do because its range of interests and agree­ ments with the Soviet Union is so broad. It is not something that an ally of the United States necessarily can do with the same degree of ease and that is becoming increasingly evident in the policies of the European allies of the United States. They are developing close economic re­ lationships with the Eastern bloc. Those economic relationship require stability in the essential re­ lationships between the individual country and the individual Eastern bloc country. They cannot lower and raise the nature of those relationships at will. Therefore they cannot, as the United States can do, respond to every particular Soviet initiative with one of their own. If at some time a catastrophe occurs like a Soviet invasion of Poland then the cut off in relations that will occur between them and the Soviet bloc will not be able, as the American relationship would be in a few years hence, to be subject to the same degree of backing and filling and perhaps a return to a non­ cold war stance that the United States could per­ haps hope for itself. A major catastrophe involv­ ing the Soviet Union would have that effect on the policies of those countries. Through the B52 agreement negotiated by the Minister while he was away, we are potentially committed to American policy in the Middle East and the Persian Gulf in particular, and yet there is no mention in the Minister's statement of this ex­ tremely important area. The B52 aircraft are inti­ mately linked with various scenarios for inter­ vention in the Middle East by the rapid deployment force. General Ellis, of the Strategic Air Command, told Congress last year: No other weapons system can match the B-52 in delivering concentrated conventional firepower on the battlefield. In the opening hours of hostilities, B-52s with 30 tons of explosives can provide timely and effective assistance in disrupting enemy actions. The projected conventional battle scenario is one characterised by minimum warn­ ing time followed by a massive attack from highly mobile forces aimed at a rapid breakthrough of defensive lines. In this situation, employment timing is critical. Ground forces need all available firepower in the first 48 hours, preferably applied directly to attacking and supporting forces. That is not very much time given the terms of the Government's agreement on consultation about other than surveillance usage of the B-52s through Darwin. It is now a matter of urgency that we in this country determine whether or not we believe that current directions in United States Middle Eastern policy are appropriate. This in­ cludes not only the question of United States pol­ icy on Arab-Israeli issues but also the current United States stress on military response to politi­ cal developments in the region, a stress which is increasingly being rejected by United States allies. It is a matter which is of increasing concern to them because they know and understand what we ought to understand-that the rapid deployment force simply cannot seize the oil installations be­ cause there are too many of them over too great a distance for that to be possible. They cannot inter­ dict a Soviet invasion, and a Soviet invasion is most unlikely because the United States and its European allies know, as we ought to know, that if the Soviet Union sought to intervene in the oil fields it would be an action that would strike at the very heart of Western economic survival, and the response to it would have to entail the severe possibility of global nuclear war. That is what de­ ters the Soviet Union in the Middle East, not a rapid deployment force that cannot arrive there in other than a division of strength even at the height of its development, at the apex of what is planned for it, in anything under a month. There is no evidence in the Minister's statement that he has given any serious consideration to this matter. This country has a direct interest in the stability of the nuclear balance between the Soviet Union and the United States. We have American facili­ ties which monitor compliance with arms control agreements, provide early warning of attack, transmit fire orders to ballistic missile submarines now capable of playing a counterforce role, and assist targeting of Soviet cities and military facili­ ties. The Minister argues, without giving us evi­ dence, that contemporary American military strategy will ensure a stable balance. He owes us more than that. Prima facie contemporary strat­ egy is likely to produce the opposite effect. In SALT II, to be abandoned by President Reagan, the United States has been provided with con­ siderable opportunities to enhance its position with regard to the Soviet Union. No projected qualitative or quantitative change planned in the deployment of American forces is precluded by SALT II-not cruise missiles, not MX missiles, not Trident missiles. On the other hand, a cap is effectively maintained on the deployment of Soviet missiles which are capable of carrying up to 30 warheads as opposed to the current half a dozen warheads. We have the right to express a view on 'these issues in the terms of agreements entered into by the Labor Government, and we have a right be­ cause of the nature of the facilities that we host. Not to have views on vital issues of nuclear arms control in these circumstances, as the Govern­ ment has not, is an abdication of responsibility. There are areas of American policy which consti­ tute a reasonable response to aspects of Soviet for­ ward policy. However, there are a substantial number which do not and which will create dis­ sension with American allies and will raise the risk of wrong signals to allies, adversaries and neutrals alike. The Foreign Mininster indicates that he values consistency in the policy of the new American Administration. There is value in con­ sistency but not if one is consistently wrong and when in a complex world achievement of it is un­ likely. There is no indication in the Minister's statement that he remotely appreciates these problems. HANSARD: DELAY IN PRODUCTION
