Speaker: Mr MCLEAN
Title: POLICY
text: Perth) (8.0)-1 welcome the statement made by the Minister for Foreign Affairs ( Mr Street) and particularly his com­ ments regarding the Reagan Administration. Dur­ ing his statement he said that he was struck by the extent to which the philosophical perspectives and the analysis of the international situation of the Reagan Administration and of the Australian Government coincided. He referred to a shared concern about the Soviet military build-up, the need to maintain a military balance as a condition for stability and effective negotiations, the need to improve consultation and co-ordination within the Western alliance and the need for purposeful American leadership. I welcome this aspect of the statement by the Minister, particularly in view of the reaction by some civic, religious and other community leaders to the statement made re­ cently by the Prime Minister ( Mr Malcolm Fraser) with respect to the assistance given to the United States of America in its surveillance of the Indian Ocean. In my view the arrangements made with the United States to allow B52 bombers access to our Air Force facilities at Darwin are extremely sen­ sible. I think Australian sovereignty has not been violated; it has been enhanced by our co-operating with our principal ally in a matter of vital stra­ tegic interest to ourselves. We have thereby con­ tributed to our own defence efforts and strengthened the ANZUS Pact on which we so heavily depend. I am at a loss to understand how critics of this policy claim that we have no com­ mon interest with the United States in the Indian Ocean. They obviously ignore the fact that the Indian Ocean is increasingly being seen by the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics as one of its spheres of influence. J think recent history pro­ vides ample evidence of this. Since Great Britain began its withdrawal from east of Suez in 1 967-Britain was then in charge of the key control points in both the eastern and western zones of the Indian Oceanthe Soviet Union has moved into fill that vacuum. The Soviet Union has treaty agreements with and access to Iraq, South Yemen, Ethiopia, I ndia and, of course, Afghanistan. Each of these countries belongs to the so-called non-aligned movement. Either I do not understand the meaning of the word 'non-aligned' or it is one of the worse mis­ nomers of all time, but the Soviets are on the island of Socotra. In 1 976 Mozambique granted the Soviet Union facilities to build air and naval POLICY installations at its Indian Ocean bases. Of course there is the improved access of the Soviet navy to the Seychelles. Since the late 1 960s Soviet naval aircraft have undertaken reconnaissance flights over the Indian Ocean. These flights have continued on a periodic basis since that time. A continuous, though fluctuating, naval presence in the Indian Ocean has been maintained, and in the past year Moscow has increased the size of its I ndian Ocean fleet to an average presence of about 30 naval units, in­ cluding guided missile cruisers, frigates and de­ stroyers, nuclear and conventional submarines, supply ships and auxiliary vessels. These naval op­ erations continue to be centred in the areas of access to the Middle East oil fields. Given the de­ pendence of the Western world on Persian Gulf oil, including the substantial dependency of the United States on this source, it is hardly surprising that the Persian Gulf now constitutes the major United States interest in the Indian Ocean. Given recent events in this region, coupled with the increasing Soviet presence there, I am surprised at the way in which the United States is vilified for increasing its military presence in that region. To suggest that Australia and the United States do not have common interests in this matter is absurd. Any number of commentators give any number of reasons for the Soviet action in this area. Some of these reasons include the securing of a sea link between the Baltic and Vladivostok, the projec­ tion of Soviet political and economic power, the denial to the West of access to resources, the op­ portunity to pressure the oil producing countries as Soviet dependency for outside oil increases, and a long term objective of moving against South Africa and its mineral wealth . These and other reasons have been put forward. But whatever the real objective may be, I think that three things are obvious: Firstly, Soviet interests and our interests do no coincide; sec­ ondly, the Soviet Union is moving to a strategic position which will enable it to achieve its objec­ tives; and thirdly, on the basis of history we can hardly assume Soviet intentions as being based on a desire to spread cheer and goodwill throughout the region. Given this kind of scenario, coupled with the fact that the United States docs not con­ trol any of the critical geographical locations that affect access to the Indian Ocean, and the critical shortage of United States bases in the Indian Ocean, I strongly support the Government's in­ itiative to assist the United States in its efforts to increase its surveillance of and presence in the Indian Ocean. At present the United States is stretching itself to the limit. The American Commander-in-Chief in the Pacific, Admiral Long, recently told the United States House of Representatives Armed Services Committee: We cannot go it alone. To the European of operations has been added a third, the Indian Ocean and the Persian Gulf. The United States is at present seeking to increase its presence in Egypt, Oman, Somalia, Kenya and Diego Garcia-but that is all in the future. Obvi­ ously the Indian Ocean nations are not doing enough and we, in Australia, must provide the United States with the kind of assistance that we are now offering if our common interests are to be properly served. I turn briefly to the I sraeli-Arab conflict. I was disappointed that the Minister's statement made no direct mention of this matter. I assume that this question is covered by the Minister's referring to the need for purposeful American leadership of the kind which led to the Camp David Accords. I hope that the United States resolve in this issue does not diminish because 1I have a feeling that the Western world is gradually moving from its long held position of strong support for the State of Israel and that there may be attempts to compro­ mise the security of Israel for other issues. During the early and mid-1 970s a shift in the debate on the Arab-Israeli peacemaking effort was taking place. The issue of boundaries was giving way to the issue of the future of the Palestinian Arabs, which we all agree must be satisfactorily resolved. At the same time the United Nations has been questioning the legitimacy of the state of Israel while the Palestine Liberation Organisation was being treated increasingly as a legal entity within the United Nations notwithstanding the fact that the PLO continues to deny the right of Israel to exist in direct contravention of unanimously car­ ried resolutions of the United Nations Security Council. This trend was continued last year by the so-called European initiative whereby the Com­ mon Market governments sought to bypass the Camp David Accords, formally to recognise the PLO and to call for the PLO's involvement in negotiations for a Middle East peace settlement. My further concern in this matter is that the United States Administration, although it made strong pro-Israeli statements during the 1 980 elec­ tion, has not as yet enunciated a policy for dealing with Arab-Israeli tensions. I ask the question: Is the United States, in pursuing broader East-West issues, going to subordinate the Arab-Israeli conflict to that of Persian Gulf security? If so, will the security of Israel be in any way compromised? In my opinion Israel has every reason to be con­ cerned with the long term trends which have been operating on this issue. I believe that the Govern­ ment should do all in its power to ensure that our support for Israel, as embraced in United Nations Security Council resolutions 242 and 338, is in no and Pacific theatres way diminished. I was interested in the Minister's comments re­ garding the linkage of various elements of any foreign policy, those elements being economic matters, human rights and strategic and political questions. These comments cannot be dissociated from my earlier remarks. I think it is quite proper for the Minister to state that although the Aus­ tralian Government believes that human rights issues are of the greatest importance it is wrong to assume that economic reform issues and human rights can be divorced from questions of security and strategy. There has been a great deal of public comment on the change in emphasis given to human rights in the formulation of foreign policy under the Reagan Administration compared with the Carter Administration. I think it was Dr Kis­ singer who said on this subject that power is the basis of foreign policy and only a country with power can have a foreign policy based on morality because only such a country has any choices. This is important in determining perceptions of other nations to the United States. In the Middle East context I think it means that a weakened United States could not behave as responsibly as once it would have done. It was President Assad who said to Kissinger: 'You sold out Vietnam and Cam­ bodia. Why should we not suppose that you will also sell out Israel?' Hence the importance of the United States again reasserting itself, both from a strategic and a moral point of view. Using human rights as the dominant organising principle of foreign affairs has meant different things to different people. It has created enor­ mous problems for the United States. Those who supported this emphasis constantly sought to dis­ credit successive United States administrations for supporting politically unattractive regimes. They maintained that if such regimes were sup­ ported the United States automatically supported their policies. To these advocates the answer was for America to come home while the Soviet Union continued its imperialistic policies. Still other advocates of this principle felt that it pro­ vided an opportunity to change things for the bet­ ter in those nations in which the United States still had some influence. Senator Moynihan, a former United States Ambassador to the United Nations, maintained that the consistent theme of those who placed human rights to the fore in foreign policy decision making was to be more concerned with the wrongdoing of the United States than with other nations that might be adversaries of the United States. A reliance on human rights alone has led to great difficulties in the United States in recent times. Firstly, it has meant that those seeking ac­ commodation with increasing Soviet power could not, quite correctly, believe that the Russians could be deterred by the threat to them of American words and arguments. Secondly, those in the United States who were prepared to stand up and respond to Soviet power were hindered by the difficulties that United States human rights policies were causing for non-communist, but equally non-democratic, nations which were United States allies. Thirdly, a quite reasonable view has been put forward by the Reagan administration that an overemphasis on human rights undermines authoritarian regimes which have a capacity for change and increases the chance that they will be succeeded by totalitarian governments, specifically communist ones, which obliterate human rights altogether. For these reasons I am pleased that the Minister raised this important issue in his statement. Obviously, if the United States is to give a lead once again to the Western world it will need to provide a greater balance between all the elements of foreign policy formulation, to which the Minister referred, which was obviously lacking in the previous Carter administration. I wish to comment briefly on the speech made by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition ( Mr Lionel Bowen) late this afternoon in reply to the ministerial statement. In the course of his 27minute speech he spent 26t minutes attacking the United States. He did not at any stage criticise the foreign policy of the Soviet Union. He did not refer to the way in which it has behaved in A fghani s t an , An go l a , H u ngary, Poland , Czechoslovakia, South Yemen, M ozambique, the Vietnamese invasion of Kampuchea or any simi­ lar issues. I thought his speech was a very unbalanced contribution, characteristic of the speeches of Labor Party spokesman in foreign affairs debates in this Parliament over the last five years. Labor Party spokesmen criticise the United States and Communist China but they will not go out of their way to criticise the Soviet Union. They seek to find a reason to defend the Soviet Union for any expansionist policy it undertakes. 1 do not welcome the arms build-up around the world. I think all of us would like to see the re­ sources of the world which are now being devoted to arms utilised to feed the millions of starving people and to increase the living standards of those who live in abject poverty. Unfortunately, that is not the reality. Until the Soviet Union and its allies change their international strategy, we have a responsibility to secure and defend this nation and give all the support we can to the United States and her allies.

Speaker: Mr MORRISON
Title: POLICY
text: St George) (8. 1 5) - The speech by the Minister for Foreign Affairs ( Mr Street) this afternoon on foreign affairs and those aspects of this Government's policy was disturb­ ing. Throughout the speech ran an emphasis on preparedness for war and a concomitant downplaying of the possibilities of peace. For in­ stance, there was no mention of efforts to reduce international tension between the great powers. For the benefit of the honourable member for Perth ( Mr MCLean) I include in that description both the Soviet Union and the United States. Detente has obviously become a seven-letter word. The Minister stated: . . . the possession of adequate power is desirable pre­ cisely because it reduces the chances of armed conflict. Regrettably, the lessons of history are otherwise. World War I and World War II showed that prep­ arations for war inexorably lead to war. The Minister has cast Australia as a middle power. I would hope that the main thrust of a middle power would be to bring some sanity to in­ ternational relations and to seek to reduce the ten­ sion between the great powers. This Government has supported, as have previous governments, both Labor and Liberal, the United Nations Dec­ laration on the Indian Ocean which aims to re­ duce tension in the Indian Ocean. It seeks to set up a zone of peace. There may be some sniggers from the Government on the concept of a zone of peace, but if we cannot get a zone of peace then we will have a zone of war. That is the issue. Very recently, in fact on 1 2 January this year, the Government supported a United Nations resol­ ution. In part that resolution stated: Considering that the continued danger posed by the mili­ tary presence of the great conceived in the context of urgency to the need to take practical steps towards the early achievement of the objectives of the Declaration of the Indian Ocean as a Zone of Peace . . . That was not simply a statement by a small government. It was a consensus statement in the United Nations that was supported by this Government. Yet in the speech by the Minister for Foreign Affairs no mention was made of this effort to reduce tension in the Indian Ocean area. I point out that the Prime Minister has personally supported a similar resolution. For instance, the communique from the Commonwealth Heads of Government Regional Meeting in New Delhi in September 1 980 stated: Heads of government noted with concern that despite the expressed wishes of the littoral and hinterland States, great power military presence in the Indian Ocean has increased and that there has been a deterioration of peace and security in the Indian Ocean area. They further noted with regret that recent events in the region, national situation, have caused a further build-up of great power military presence. Neither of these sane and sensible statements was included in the Minister's speech. Regrettably, in practice the Government has taken steps not to decrease tension but to increase it. Many of us will recall that just prior to the general election, in a fit of ridiculous p osturing, the Government dispatched the main operating units of the Royal Australian Navy into the Indian Ocean. It was de­ scribed as the largest and longest Indian Ocean deployment by the RAN since World War 11again this emphasis on war. The Government said the ships were to exercise with the navies of a number of friendly powers and would visit a large number of ports. The deployment was a monu­ mental flop. There were no major exercises with other navies and the number of ports visited was reduced. In a last minute decision the units were pulled out of an exercise in the northern Indian Ocean with units from the United Kingdom and the United States. That was a sensible decision, but it made a nonsence of the Government's pre­ election posturing. So we can say: 'So much for the Minister's only sensible piece of advice in his speech, that we should not extend ourselves unrealistically. ' The Minister's statement is remarkable in another sense. It displays a yawning gap between the principles espoused and the Government's actual performance. The Minister in his speech pointed to a feature of what he describes as middle power foreign policy; that is, that quality of performance is particularly important in deter­ mining influence and status. H is regrettable that this Government's quality of performance in a number of areas of foreign policy, particularly in Powers in the Indian Ocean area, their confrontation, gives greater Kampuchea, is deficit in relation to their aims. The Minister dealt with Kampuchea at length in his speech. I want to draw the House's attention to a statement on Kampuchea issued by the then Minister for Foreign Affairs on 14 October 1980. [ think the first thing we should note about the statement is the date14 October 1 980, precisely four days before the Federal election. There was, as you will recall, Mr Deputy Speaker, a strong criticism within the then Government, the Liberal Party, about relations with Kampuchea. There was a disenchantment among supporters of the Liberal Party about the Government's policy towards Kampuchea in continuing recognition of the Pol Pot regime. So something had to be done in the pre-election panic. The statement that was issued on that occasion was intended to give the impression that the Government had derecog­ nised the Pol Pot regime, Democratic Kam­ puchea. In fact the statement said: together with the worsening inter­ The Minister for Foreign Affairs, Mr Andrew Peacock, said today that Australia has taken a decision in effect to derecog­ nise the Government of Democratic Kampuchea (the Pol Pot regime) . As we are all aware, it took the Government another four months to the day1 4 February 1981 - to state that the derecognition of the Government of Democratic Kampuchea, the Pol Pot regime, would take effect as from that day. That statement of 1 4 October-four days before the election-was nothing more than a deceptive piece of window-dressing. It was in fact a con­ fidence trick. But there was another deception built into the Government's statement of 1 4 October. That statement followed by only a few hours instruc­ tions to Australia's United Nations delegatiqn to vote in favour of Democratic Kampuchea in the credentialling committee of the United Nations. That meant that Australia, irrespective of what it did a couple of hours later, voted for the con­ tinued recognition of the Pol Pot regime. The Government's inconsistency is patently obvious. On the one hand it sought to give the impression that it had derecognised the Pol Pot regime and on the other it voted to continue that recognition. We should remember that the United Nations is the only forum in which recognition of a country with which we do not have diplomatic relations has any relevance. The United Nation is the only organisation in which recognition or derecogni­ tion of Democratic Kampuchea has any relevance. In 1 979 the Government adopted the policy­ and this is getting back to the history of the credentialling committee-of the previous Liberal-Country Party administrations in arguing, and arguing quite spuriously, that credentialling of delegations in the United Nations is a technical and legal matter and not a matter of policy. For decades the Liberal and Country parties followed that line by denying the very existence of Commu­ nist China. By this ploy it upheld the fiction that Taiwan was the rightful government of China. But in 1 979 the Australian Government missed an opportunity because in the debate in the United Nations the Indian delegation put forward a proposal-a very sensible proposal-that the seat of Kampuchea should be left vacant. But, oh no, attached to this great ostrich-like policy of con­ tinuing to recognise the Pol Pot regime, the Aus­ tralian delegation voted against the Indian del­ egation's proposal. One of the consequences of that decision was that the Indian Government then decided to recognise the Heng Samrin regime in Kampuchea. This meant that the support that India could have given to proposals put forward by members of the Association of South East Asian Nations and other countries for a settle­ ment in Kampuchea was lost. The whole import of what Australia has done in the United Nations has been to continue to give international respectability it continues today to give international respectability-to the Pol Pot regime because by that vote the Pol Pot regime has full membership status in the United Nations and in the United Nations' specialised agencies and regional organisations for the whole of 1981 . confrontation, That recognition still continues. It is not just an academic question. Only last week the Australian delegation to the United Nations Economic and Social Committee for Asia and the Pacific held in Bangkok and led by a Minister of this Govern­ ment sat at the very same table as a representative of the Pol Pot regime. The Australian delegation did not protest the presence of the Pol Pot rep­ resentative. By its action it has continued to recog­ nise the Pol Pot regime. In short, this Government has misled this House and, more importantly, the Australian p eople. If it is the intention of the Minister for Foreign Affairs to place an emphasis on the qual­ ity of performance of a middle power the first thing that the Government must do is act consist­ ently and act honestly. That is the intent of any foreign policy that an Australian government should seek to perform. This Government has not acted consistently; it has not acted honestly. In fact, it has not acted in the way that we on this side of the House believe Australia as a middle power should perform.

Speaker: Mr FALCONER
Title: POLICY
text: Casey) (8.29)-The House is debating a statement made by the Minister for Foreign Affairs ( Mr Street) concerning the nature of this country's foreign policy and some of the more urgent tasks facing us. In replying to the Minister the Deputy Leader of the Opposition ( Mr Lionel Bowen) made one comment that I want to take up at this stage. He said that the 'new United States Administration had scrapped human rights as an instrument of foreign policy. I think that is one of the many dangerous over­ simplifications which the Deputy Leader of the Opposition made during his speech. I want to quote from an interview which Mr Alexander Haig, the United States Secretary of State, gave to Time magazine. He was in fact asked a question on that very point. He was asked about the sig­ nificance of human rights diplomacy in American policy at present, and he said: We are concerned that open societies sometimes get vic­ timised by the practical consequences of their openness and by the lack of access to information about totalitarian regimes where, it is our conviction, the major abuses to human rights are occurring today. But this is an ancillary problem related to our more strongly held concern that past human rights poli­ cies have in many instances been counterproductive, not only to the objective of strengthening human rights but also from the standpoint of vital American interests. He went on: There are a number of questions related to this. First and foremost, we must continue to be deeply concerned about abuses to human rights wherever they occur; but there are such questions as whether amelioration of those abuses is best achieved under the glare of public criticism and animosity and or whether it is best achieved in a quieter dia­ logue between states with a healthier relationship. What I want to point out is that there are many ways of approaching human rights questions, many ways of trying to deal with them where we are dealing with relationships with sovereign countries, and I think it is unreasonable to assert in a sweeping manner that the United States has effectively scrapped human rights as an instru­ ment of foreign policy. There can be differences about approach, there can be differences about the end result of various courses of action with re­ spect to human rights and how effective various courses of action mayo be, but in fact it is still a very strong element of United States policy, and indeed should be. Mr Haig's remarks point to a problem that we face in Australia. There is tendency in Australia, in talking about human rights problems, to em­ phasise problems that appear in countries such as Indonesia, the Philippines and South Korea. These are countries which are more open than many of the communist or left wing countries in the region. Therefore one has a greater oppor­ tunity to find out about instances of breaches of human rights. However, one does not have the same opportunity to obtain information about what is happening in more closed societies, in societies which are often run by socialist or com­ munist governments, or governments that claim to have that complexion. So effectively a great public emphasis on human rights issues can lead to a sense of protection being given to closed societies which do not allow us to find out what is going on in their countries compared with more open societies where there is a greater possibility for use to move in or send people into find out what is happening and therefore bring the abuses of human rights to light. That is one of the difficul­ ties that those of us in Australia who want to take action on human rights face in dealing with the situation in an even-handed manner. The honourable member for St George ( Mr Morrison) said that the lessons of World War I and World War II show that preparations for war inexorably led to war. There is an element of truth in that, but perhaps the word 'inexorably' is over­ stating it. Many others would say that prep­ arations for war ensure that we do not face war in future because we deter future enemies. The example that is commonly given to support that argument is the example of the development of power in nazi Germany in the 1 930s and the lack of response by democratic countries to that chal­ lenge which was obviously looming on the hor­ izon. What we want is not an oversimplified state­ ment about preparations for war; what we want is a realistic assessment of what is happening in the world and an appropriate response to what that assessment shows. With that in mind I want to examine some of the attitudes being adopted by the Reagan Administration towards the Soviet Union, and then to look at the implications of those attitudes for Australian foreign policy. One of the problems in American attitudes towards the Soviet Union, in recent years is that there has tended to be a swing from one unreal view to another. [n some circles in the United States there has been an undue naivety about the potential to reach some peaceful accommodation with the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics. It was an attitude evi­ dent in much of the eastern liberal academic es­ tablishment of the United States of America. Many people in that category tended to take the view that if only we understood the USSR and got to know each other as people through more. cul­ tural exchanges, sporting contacts, regular consul­ tations, et cetera, our fears of the USSR would fade and we would come to realise that we are all human beings of peaceful intent with common interests. Some people who take this view have a tendency to be highly critical of American leader­ ship for supposedly having passed up opportuni­ ties to lessen tensions between the two super­ powers. In my view these unreal expectations arise from a lack of knowledge, of Russian history, both czarist and Bolshevik, and a lack of under­ standing of the essential dynamics of policies aris­ ing from Marxist-Leninist theories. The Soviet Union sees itself as being on the historically cor­ rect side of a fundamental ideological conflict be­ tween the forces of socialism and the forces of capitalism. These factors incline the Soviet Union towards an aggressive and expansionist attitude. Addto this some of the tensions within the Soviet Union itself, the failure of its economy to deliver the standard of living which had been promised to the Soviet people, and that increases also the like­ lihood that any Soviet government will be looking for outside adventures or at least be looking for some outside tensions which it can use to distract attention from problems within the country. Certainly we must understand the very real fears of the Russian people, the people who suffered at the hands of nazi Germany in the Sec­ ond World War. A very real basis of fear exists among people in the Soviet Union, perhaps even to the extent of some sort of xenophobic attitude towards countries around the Soviet Union. That is something that we must bear in mind and with which we must sympathise. At the same time we must realise that there are essential forces within Soviet societies, within Marxist and Leninist the­ ory, which tend to give the Soviet Union an expansionist attitude towards the rest of the world. One problem with the unreal attitude towards the Soviet Union, which I described earlier that if only we could get to know each other as people a bit more then tensions would lessen, is that when some incident occurs which breaks down that attitude of trust and general bonhomie, it can lead to a swing in the direction of excessive mistrust and bellicosity. So one can get a return to the bluster, the abuse, and the general tense language of Cold War rhetoric. We all re­ call, for example, how President Carter made himself look a rather pathetic figure when he complained, after the Soviet Union invasion of Afghanistan, that the Soviet Union had misled him. We then saw something of a tendency in the United States for congressmen, for leading spokesmen on public opinion, to swing towards bellicosity and sabre rattling. in the terms of their attitudes to foreign relations and in particular their attitudes towards Russia. What then do we make of the rather strident statements which are now coming from President Reagan and Secretary of State Haig? A common fear being expressed by many commentators that the language of Mr Reagan and Mr Haig may raise unnecessarily the temperature of relation­ ships and increase the risk of some genuine misun­ derstanding arising between the super-powers about their intentions. That misunderstanding could then raise the risk of actual cOIiflict. Doubt­ less the new Administration feels that the United' States needs to show more resolve and, purpose ,in its foreign policies than has been demonstrated recent years. Perhaps some stiffening of United world . . States resolve is indeed needed at this stage. In that respect, the recent statements by President Reagan may reflect the developments that would have occurred under any President likely to b.e elected in the current political atmosphere. By now, however, I think, the, rhetorical points hav\:l been made. I think some degree of excessive emotionalism has been used in some of the language that has come out of Washington, but that United States resolve should now be ex­ pressed by way of the iron fist in a velvet giove ap­ proach rather than by waving a cutlass around ac: companied by blood curdling screams. Neither United States leaders nor Australian leaders should fall into the trap of abusing the Soviet Union and its leaders merely to satisfy some emotional requirement in themselves. In the Australian context" as we are developing closer and more fruitful relationships with China, it is particularly easy to see our interests in 'the short term being served by a stridency towards Soviet Union that brings satisfied smiles to the faces of Chinese trade delegations. I have prob­ ably fallen into this trap myself in the presence affable Chinese officials when we have both found common cause in bemoaning the tendencies of the Soviet Union. I believe we would .be wise to to ensure that our foreign policy does not tip too strongly in favour of China vis-a-vis the Soviet Union. After all, the United States opening to China under the Nixon Administration, by which Australia's rapprochement with China became more possible, was not an initiative designed to form some United States-China alliance against the Soviet Union. Both President Nixon and Dr Kissinger, the then National Security adviser and after that Secretary of State were at great pains to point out that the detente with China was not intended to lead to a United States-China condo­ minium to surround the Soviet Union. Rather it was seen as a way of bringing China out of her iso­ lation and ensuring China her rightful place in an overall world balance. I do not believe our desire to pursue harmoni­ ous relationships with China should lead us to court unnecessary aggravations in any re1ation­ is ship we have with the Soviet Union. In other words, we do not need to be rude to the Russians in order to charm the Chinese. I do not say this in any belief that we can afford to be soft or com­ pl;icent in our attitude to the Soviet Union. On the contrary, as I said earlier, we must be fully aware of the fundamental ideological struggle be­ tween the Soviet Union and western liberal democracies and the possibility of this developing in into armed conflict at various points around the This ha.s ' implications for Australian foreign policy. 'Within the context of that super-power re­ lationship between the United States and the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics I believe we have a very real role to play. There is no real alternative to Australia being part of the American alliance in both a military and diplo­ matic sense. Ideologically our society has nothing in common with basic Marxist structures, no mat­ ter how much any briefly fashionable romantics in our country like to wear Mao badges or pay hom­ age to whatever other Marxist leader happens to be in vogue at the time. Our commitment to West­ ern Liberal democratic traditions and the basic freedoms of such societies gives us a fundamental common ' interest with the United States. The Australian people would feel that they have some natural alliance with the American people whether or not that alliance was formalised in a treaty. In fact, it is formalised in a treaty in the the form of the ANZUS treaty. That treaty allows us to play a constructive role of influence in our re­ lationships with the United States. We have the of opportunity of having some input into United States policy considerations. We share the results 01 intelligence gathering, a matter of great benefit Australia. I believe that also imposes on us a re­ sponsibility to play a . part in enabling the United States to carry out its global responsibilities. I do not want to suggest that the American al­ liance is the be-all and end-all of all Australian foreign policy and defence policy. We must de­ velop our own regional network of bilateral and multilateral relationships. Under this Govern­ ment we have developed practical working re­ lationships with a number of countries in our region.

text: Fraser) (8.44) -1 must say how pleasing it was to hear the honourable member for Casey ( Mr Falconer) delivering such a moderate and well reasoned speech, in sharp contrast to many of his colleagues. It is always a pleasure to listen to the honourable member for Casey be­ cause he analyses the issue at stake. He attempts to understand the point of view of the other side and gives a reasonable assessment of it. That is in sharp contrast to the honourable member for Perth ( Mr MCLean) , for instance, who always gives a very bellicose, reactionary sort of speech and distorts the Labor viewpoint. 1 must refute the honourable member's accusation that Aus­ tralian Labor Party policy is pro-Soviet and anti­ American. Every Labor member who spoke in this debate said that we should not have a point of view that was pro any other nation. Our policy should not necessarily go along with the Russians, the Americans, the Indians, the Chinese or any­ one else. We are saying that we should look at situations objectively and develop our own policy. That is precisely what we do not do. The sorts of views put forward by the honourable member for Casey conform to that view. I was very disappointed and saddened by the ease with which the new Minister for Foreign A ffairs ( Mr Street) has so quickly and pliantly fallen into line to comply with what we see as the tunnel vision of his leader, the hard-line people his party and the reactionary leaders in the world today such as the Reagans and the Thatchers. It is very sad that those people tend to see things in black and white; they do not see anything in be­ tween. Other people are either with them or against them. They do not try to understand the point of view of the other side. The Minister for Foreign Affairs visited countries which he refers to as like-minded countries. They include most of the Association for South East Asian Nation countries-Thailand, the Philippines, Malaysia. He also visited places such as Tokyo, Peking and Washington. He says that those countries are like­ minded. He should realise that all those countries still support the Pol Pot regime which we have only belatedly derecognised. If those countries are like-minded he is being very honest in saying that at least they still support the Pol Pot regime and that they see people who support the Pol Pot regime as like-minded people. It is a great shame that the Minister did not try to be better informed by talking to officials in some countries which were not like-minded which may have been able to enlighten him and give him a more objective view of the situations on the ground. The Minister did not go to any of those countries. If he had he would have had a different view. By talking only to like-minded people how does one get out of having a tunnel vision of the situation in those countries? Of c'ourse, the tunnel vision leads the Min ister to the wrong conclusion-as it has led the Government to the wrong conclusion-that communism and big power politics are the enemy particularly ' in South East Asia. The Government should be looking toward going back to the root-cause of the problem in South East Asia. The root-causes of the problem are the denial of basic human rights to the popu­ lation at large in many of those countries; gross poverty and starvation for millions of people; gross underdevelopment; and gross corruption in many of the regimes. These are the problems to which we should address ourselves, not some vague abstraction called communism. That tunnel vision leads people to the further view that insta­ bility in those countries is caused by big power involvement. There is no question about the fact that big powers become involved. Big powers are involved in Kampuchea. Their involvement is made possible by the instability in those countries caused by the poverty, the underdevelopment and, in some cases-as in Kampuchea and Vietnam-by the involvement of Western coun­ tries such as the United States of America. West­ ern countries went into that region and created in the conditions which allowed instability to de­ velop. They destroyed the social infrastructure of those countries, and moved out and left a vacuum. Extreme people such as Pol Pot were able to move into that vacuum with devastating effects on the community. We did the same sort of thing in Vietnam. We said: 'The problem is that the south is being invaded from the north', without looking at the internal position in South Vietnam. The instability was internal and not caused only by external forces. We seem to be making the same sorts of judg­ ments in South East Asia, Kampuchea and, of course, El Salvador. I am sorry that the Minister did not look at these countries, make himself bet­ ter informed and form a more balanced view of what is going on. My wife and I recently visited Vietnam, Kam­ puchea and Phnom Penh. We found that visit very interesting and very enlightening. We came back with a much better balanced view of what is happening in these countries. If the Minister had gone there he would have a different view from the one he has expressed. He would not have any truck at all with countries which are supporting the Pol Pot regime, or he would try to encourage them to derecognise Pol Pot. If the Minister or anybody else has any doubts about the demonic and horrendous nature of the Pol Pot regime they should look at the photographs which my wife took on the outskirts of Phnom Penh where thou­ sands of human skeletons are being dug out of the ground. Mainly these are skeletons of women and children. It is stark and horrendous evidence of how bad the Pol Pot regime was. If one were to go there and see that and talk the people one would not be talking about the not on. Vietnamese invading Kampuchea. There is no question that the people in Phnom Penh today see the Vietnamese as their saviours. They are regarded as fraternal people who came into them from the horrors of Pol Pot. These people are damned glad to be alive. They recognise that. On our visit to Phnom Penh we would not have know the Vietnamese presence was there. We did not see one Vietnamese soldier in Phnom Penh. We knew they were there because the Kam­ puchean people told us they were being assisted by the Vietnamese. We know they have 200,000 troops in the north keeping the Pol Pot forces check. I can assure honourable members that they are exercising a very benign influence over Kampucheans. The Kampuchean economy is developing in a complete laissez faire, free market atmosphere. The Heng Samrin regime is allowing the normal market forces to operate so that the country can develop an economy. The proof is shown in the Vietnam. fact that there are now 300,000 people back in Phnom Penh. They are coming back in large very numbers. Many of them have come out of the ref­ ugee camps which twelve months ago were seen an insoluble problem. They are coming back be­ cause they have confidence in the Heng Samrin regime and in the way in which it is running the country. The children are back at school. There are not many teachers because Pol Pot cut the throats of most of them. Agriculture is recovering rapidly. The regime has the support of the people in Phnom Penh. I did not get out into the country so I cannot speak for the people there. I have of other people who have toured extensively through the country and the story is the same: They are very grateful for the fact that the Viet­ namese came in and saved them from the Pol Pot regime. To talk about the Vietnamese invading the Kampucheans, dominating them and standing over them is a complete misreading of the situation. I can understand the Minister's holding that view because he did not talk to anybody who has a different view and he did not go and look for him­ self. If he had done so he would have seen that the Vietnamese were not aggressors. If the Kam­ pucheans want the Vietnamese to get out they know what to do. All they have to do is to encour­ age some of their like-minded friends to derecog­ nise Pol Pot and stop giving him support, and the Vietnamese will withdraw the next day. It is very costly for the Vietnamese to be in Kampuchea. They do not want to be there but they will not turn their backs on their brothers in Kampuchea to and let them be slaughtered by Pol Pot. It is just It is quite absurd for the Minister to talk about supporting the third force. The third force is save comprised of people who are not even in Kam­ puchea. It has very little grassroots support. It is absolute nonsense to talk of supporting the third force led by Prince Sihanouk or anybody else. The reality of the situation is that the Vietnamese are there. They will stay there. They have been there for a long time. They have supported the Kampucheans consistently. They supported them in getting rid of the French. They supported them in against the Lon N ol regime and they have now supported them in getting rid of Pol Pot. There is the nothing n ew about Vietnam supporting Kampuchea. More and more countries are now recognising that the Indo-China region is a legit­ imate area of influencc of Vietnam. Vietnam has a population of 40 million or 50 million people. Kampuchea and Laos are both very small coun­ tries. They are vital to the peace and prosperity of As I said, my wife and I went to Vietnam. It is a rundown country. It is badly in need of aid and support. I found it very distressing and I felt as quite ashamed of our Government in that the little bit of aid that we were giving them was c�t off. The condensed milk factory which we sel'lt them is sitting in crates. There' is nobody there to assemble it. We sent them 600 head of beef cattle. We were supposed to follow up with a pasture im­ provement program. In a very petty act we just cut off that program. Whilst it was only symbolic support, its being stopped has created very bad read feeling between our Government and the Govern­ ment of Vietnam, although the Vietnamese know there are many people in Australia who would not have agreed with what happened. It is a great shame that the Minister did not go and look at that area, but I know that the Prime Minister ( Mr Malcolm Fraser) would not want him to go to see the situation for himself. The Government has a tunnel vision about what is going on in the country and does not want that disturbed. Normally we take our lead from the Associ­ ation of South East Asian Nations in developing a policy towards Kampuchea. On this occasion, although publicly the ASEAN nations are saying they are opposed to the Vietnamese, privately at least two of them, the Indonesians and the Malaysians, have some sympathy for the Viet­ namese position. I wish to say a few words briefly on El Salvador. This is another example of a misguided policy of the Americans insisting on sending guns when the President of EI Salvador stated that the strongest army in the world would not overcome the prob­ lems of poverty and starvation in that country. It is nonsense for us to be screaming out about these people acquiring arms. My son visited that country last year. He wrote to me and stated how horrifying it was to see, 1 2 months ago, the national guard in EI Salvador shooting demon­ strators in the back. In the last 1 2 months thou­ sands of innocent peasant people in EI Salvador have been shot down with weapons which were supplied by the Americans to the national guard in EI Salvador. What are these people to do? Are they to sit down and be shot? Of course they will secure weapons. Whether they get them from the Americans or a communist country is irrelevant. These people are driven to desperation. They have to defend themselves. It does not matter where they get the weapons from. If the Americans listened to the advice of the President of the Government of EI Salvador, they would be aware that he said: 'We do not want guns. We want economic aid. We want to be able to develop our country. We want to be able to feed ourselves'. But the Americans say: 'No, you do not want aid. You want more guns to shoot all these revolutionary people'. That is the situation as it is developing in EI Salvador today. I think anyone who really believes that in the long term we can sustain indefinitely this gross social injus­ tice involving the majority of the people in the world, mainly those in the underdeveloped coun­ tries of the Third World who are living in abject poverty, fighting starvation and undevelopment without basic health and education facilities, shows no understanding of the recognition of the continued long term progress towards social jus­ tice to which every nation is entitled.

Speaker: Mr VINER
Title: HUMAN RIGHTS COMMISSION BILL
text: Stirling-Minister for Employ­ ment and Youth Affairs) (9.0)-I move: That the Bill be now read a second time. The purpose of this Bill is to establish a Common­ wealth Human Rights Commission. The Com­ mission will promote the observance of human rights throughout Australia within the limits of Commonwealth power. In co-operation with the States on human rights matters the Commission will assist the Government in discharging its inter­ national obligations in the cause of human rights. Our intention to introduce this legislation was foreshadowed in the Government's policy speech prior to the last election. The most recent attempt by this Government to have Parliament approve a human rights commission foundered because of lack of agreement between this House and the Senate on what became known as the Simon amendment, and was related to the rights of the child before as well as after birth. The Govern­ ment has arrived at a formula, included in this Bill, which it believes will be acceptable both to those who voted for and those who voted against the amendments. Since the Human Rights Commission Bill 1 979 was debated in this House last year, several events have transpired which only add to the need for effective human rights machinery in Australia. In August 1 980, Australia ratified the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights. To date 65 countries have become parties to this Covenant, many of which have established their own special forms of machinery to promote and protect human rights. The measure riow before the House, and the Commission that would be established under it, will help Australia to dis­ charge the obligations it has assumed under the covenant. Last August, as well, the Government estab­ lished the Human Rights Bureau as an interim measure pending creation of a human rights com­ mission. Recently, the Bureau has begun to re­ ceive representations from the public in the form of complaints, requests for assistance, and re­ quests for information in the general field of human rights. The Bureau has also made sig­ nificant progress in establishing links with non­ government organisations in the human rights field. It is apparent, however, that there is a need for more effective machinery to promote human rights in Australia than is available through the Bureau, and it is the object of the Bill to provide this machinery. The Commission will not be a large undertaking. Its emphasis will be on quality. Its annual cost is currently estimated at about $850,000, to which will be added the cost of the Office of the Commissioner for Community Relations-estimated at $ 350,000 in 1 980-8 1 . The main provisions of the Bill are the same as in the Bill considered by the House last year. As such, they have already been the subject of con­ siderable discussion and debate. I intend in this speech, therefore, to refer to and explain only those changes from the 1 979 Bill that are found in the present measure. The only change of sig­ nificance is that the charter of the Commission has been extended to three additional inter­ national instruments. As with the previous Bill, the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights will be the primary point of reference for the Commission. However, in response to the con­ cern expressed in this House, and also in the Senate, during the debate on the Simon amend­ ment about the rights of both children and handi­ capped persons, the Commission will also be required to have regard, in areas of Common­ wealth responsibility, for the rights of these groups as recognised in three international declar­ ations, each of which has been supported by Australia. The three declarations are-the Dec­ laration of the Rights of the child, 1 9 59; the laration on the Rights of the Mentally Retarded, 1 9 7 1 ; and the Declaration on the Rights of the Disabled, 1 975. The Declaration of the Rights of the Child recognises that the Child, by reason of his physical and mental immaturity, needs special safeguards and care, including appropriate legal protection, before as well as after birth. The declaration also calls upon men and women everywhere, on volun­ tary organisations and on governments to strive for the observance of the rights of the child which it proclaims. The rights include the right to special protection to enable the child to develop fully; the right to enjoy the benefits of social security, in­ cluding adequate pre-natal and post-natal care; and the rights to education and to protection from cruelty and exploitation. Similarly, the two dec­ larations concerned with the rights of physically and intellectually handicapped persons call for national and international action to protect the rights they declare. The rights of the intellectually handicapped include the right to be accorded as far as possible the same rights as other persons; the right to economic security and a decent stan­ dard of living; and the right to protection from ex­ ploitation, abuse and degrading treatment. The rights of the physically handicapped include the right to the same civil and political rights as other persons; the right to respect for their human dig­ nity; the right to measures to enable them to be­ come as self-reliant as possible; and the rights to medical and other treatment and to economic and social security and a decent level of living. The three declarations I have just been describ­ ing do not represent commitments in inter­ national law, as does the Covenant on Civil and Political Rights. But they express important aspir­ ations, and we are proposing that the Commission should monitor, and report on, the way in which Commonwealth departments and agencies, and activities generally in the Australian Capital Ter­ ritory, are conforming with them. The three dec­ larations are defined in clause 3 of the Bill, and are included in the definition of 'human rights' in the same clause. There are consequential amend­ ments, chiefly in clause 3 1 , which envisage the declaration of further international instruments as part of the Commission's charter. During debate on the 1 979 Bill and in the ensu­ ing months, comments have been made about cer­ tain aspects of the 1 979 Bill that are repeated in the present Bill. Because they are apparently the source of some concern, I should like to discuss three of those criticisms. The first is that the scope of the proposed Commission would extend only to Dec­ laws of the Commonwealth and the Territories except the Northern Territory-and actions or procedures under such laws. The Commission's mandate will not extend to State or Northern Ter­ ritory laws or actions or procedures of State and Northern Territory authorities. However, clause 1 1 of the Bill provides for a range of co-operative arrangements to be entered into with the States and it is the Government's intention and expec­ tation that this mechanism will be fully used. The ministerial meeting on human rights will continue to exercise a role at top policy level in considering issues which require consultation be­ tween the various levels of government and in promoting generally the cause of human rights in Australia. Accordingly, this Bill manifests the Government's continuing commitment to co­ operative federalism, which is already developing well in the human rights field. The second criti­ cism levelled at the 1 979 Bill is that the proposed Commission would incorporate the Office of the Commissioner for Community Relations. Non­ government organisations in the human rights field have particularly voiced this concern. It is motivated by a fear that the work done by the Commissioner for Community Relations will somehow be interrupted or curtailed. The Government's expectation is in fact quite the op­ posite. Let me emphasise, as I did when the pre­ vious Bill was before the House, that the Com­ missioner for Community Relations will continue to carry out the complaint-handling and concili­ ation functions associated with administration of the Racial Discrimination Act. Further, the added resources of the Commission will be avail­ able to assist as required in the important task of combating racial discrimination, and there will be a recourse, as there was not previously, to the Meeting of Ministers on Human Rights on racial discrimination matters. The Government is confident, therefore, that establishing the Commission will not make less effective the role of the Commissioner for Com­ munity Relations in dealing with complaints of racial discrimination. Thirdly, there have been criticisms that the Human Rights Commission is being given inadequate powers�that it has no machinery for enforcement of its findings. That criticism represents a misunderstanding of the essential purpose of the Commission. The purpose of the Commission is to promote discussion and understanding of human rights in the community generally and to recommend to the Government and to Parliament changes in law or practice required to bring that law and practice into line with human rights as defined by the International Covenant or other human rights instruments. For its job, the Commission has been given adequate powers to obtain papers, to call witnesses, to con­ duct hearings and to make reports. A survey of in­ stitutions with similar functions in Australia and overseas shows that the Commission is as well, or better, endowed with powers than other bodies having similar functions. What the critics of the Commission suggest is that it should have some kind of court-like powers of enforcement. In the view of the Government, this may be a possible step for the future, but it is not the next step, which is establishment of the Commission. It is only when the Parliament has laid down laws relating to human rights in a par­ ticular area�for example relating to racial discrimination�that the normal law enforcement machinery should be considered. Even there, the clear cut and authoritative decisions of the courts may not be the correct way to proceed, at any rate in the early stages of the operation of the law. The promotion of human rights in this country will be achieved more through education, through finding new balances of interests and through con­ ciliation than through firm measures of enforce­ ment. In closing, I should like to refer to the final paragraph of my second reading speech for the 1 979 Bill. The thoughts and hopes expressed are as current and important today as they were then. I said: Human rights are about the protection of individuals. I be­ lieve, and the Government believes, that in an era of social change in which governments exercise wide powers and cor­ porations and large institutions greatly influence the lives of individuals, it is important to have an agency that is active in the protection and promotion of the rights of individuals. We see in the world around us too many occasions where the rights of individuals are cruelly violated. The purpose of the Human Rights Commission, and of the machinery associated with it, is to help Australia maintain its excellent record in the protection of human rights, and progressively to develop a better and more comprehensive recognition and observance of the rights of every individual in our community, regardless of financial standing and whatever his or Iter race, age, sex, re­ ligion or status. I commend the Bill to the House. Debate (on motion by Mr John Brown) adjourned. NA AMENDMENT BILL 1981 Bill received from the Senate, and read a first time. Second Reading

Speaker: Mr FRY
Title: RACIAL DISCRIMINATION
text: Fraser) (9. l 3) - When the debate on the Complaints (Australian Federal Police) Bill was adjourned I was pointing out how important it is in any democratic society that citizens the right and the means to seek redress for injus­ tices perpetrated by organs of the state, including the police. In Australia one such important organ is the Australian Federal Police and the Bill vides the public with the means of achieving a sat­ isfactory investigation of almost all types of griev­ ances linked with the Australian Federal Police. Most importantly, the Bill seeks to establish mechanism that will not hamstring members of the Australian Federal Police in carrying out their vital role in the community. By strengthening role of the Ombudsman, the Bill seeks to strike sensible balance between providi�g the public with a guarantee that their grievances will be en­ ergetically and conscientiously investigated and, at the same time, screening the authorities from malicious and destructive complaints. However, the Bill still has some minor gaps which could be plugged. I refer to the provision which the Ombudsman has the power to hire police officers to investigate particular com­ plaints. This is set out fairly clearly. It would the benefit of the legislation and would assist Ombudsman if that power were extended to the but hiring of former police officers. people may be sceptical of the objectivity of a former officer, since there is provision for the ing of existing police officers in certain circum­ stances, there could be very good grounds for ing a former police officer if it were clear that deep knowledge of police procedure would great advantage in ensuring a thorough investi­ gation. I am sure that the Ombudsman's office would exercise that right with great discretion. The Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs ( Mr Viner) may care to comment on that proposal. My other concern with the Bill is the potential problem presented by the sub judice law. The Minister may care to comment on that matter also and indicate whether the Ombudsman could be inhibited in any way by such law. It could happen frequently that, the police having taken action Second Reading against a citizen, as a result of which charges have been laid, the citizen may wish to lay a counter­ charge against the police. I can imagine a situation in which the Ombudsman may be inhibited in his investigation by the sub judice law. I believe he use his discretion in handling such a situ­ ation. However, it could present a problem and I would like the Minister to make clear whether the the Ombudsman would be inhibited by the sub judice law. When many complaints are being made against the police it often becomes quite apparent that problems of morale exist within the police force have itself. That has been my experience in the Aus­ tralian Capital Territory. The recent amalga­ mation of the old Commonwealth Police and the Australian Capital Territory Police was charac­ pro­ terised by many teething problems. Over time many of these have been eliminated, but others re­ main. In that respect, I know that members of the Protective Services Division feel that they have a been disadvantaged in the amalgamation, in re­ gard to wages and salaries in particular. I believe they have a legitimate complaint. A recent deter­ the mination, of August 1 980, although it covered a people performing general police duties did not extend benefits to members of the Protective Ser­ vices Division, who lag considerably behind other officers in that respect. It is possible for police officers performing exactly the same work to be receiving significantly different rates of pay-the difference sometimes being as much as $2,000 a by year. The present Minister has been sympathetic to complaints made by the Protective Services Division and I believe he will continue to examine be to these problems and overcome them as they arise. the Many of the initial problems have been overcome, the wages issue is still a matter of concern for Although some quite a few officers. Another problem is that there is still difficulty hir­ in obtaining suitable uniforms for some policemen and policewomen. I understand that there are no hir­ winter uniforms available for the women a members of the Protective Services Division, and be a with winter coming up pretty quickly, the Government should apply itself to the problem and ensure that the morale of the people perform­ ing this important work is maintained. If there is good morale in the force fewer complaints are made against it by the public. The Complaints (Australian Federal Police) Bill 1981 is an im­ portant step forward for Australia. I hope that its spirit will be copied by all other States. I com­ mend the Bill to the House.

Speaker: Mr DONALD CAMERON
Title: RACIAL DISCRIMINATION
text: F adden) (9.20 ) -1 want to compliment the Australian Law Reform Commission, which, as all honour­ able members know, is headed by Mr Justice Michael Kirby, on the success it has had over the years. It could be said that the Commission has not won approval for everything it has recom­ mended. I suggest it has won more approval than the Opposition and the back bench of the Govern­ ment side of this Parliament have managed to win in the last five, six or even ten years. Not every­ thing put forward by the Law Reform Com­ mission commands my agreement, but it has had more than its share of success. The Complaints (Australian Federal Police) Bill is one example of its suggestions not only being taken seriously by the Government but also being acted upon and in­ corporated in the nation's legislation. I am keen to speak on this Bill so that I can ex­ press the view that this legislation should be regarded as the ideal by all State police forces within the Commonwealth of Australia. As you are fully aware, Mr Deputy Speaker, I come from the State of Queensland. I think that was your home State before you shifted to New South Wales. Undoubtedly the Queensland Police Force, like the police force of every other State, subjected to varying degrees of criticism from time to time. Some say that the Queensland Police Force is the worse in Australia for its appreciation of the liberties of the individual, and others say that from time to time police forces from other States take that prize. r do not intend to enter into the question of which State has the best or the worse police force. However, I make the observation that an individ­ ual policeman is in some cases probably without full appreciation or knowledge of the power that he possesses. There lies in his hands a greater ability to destroy the lifestyle of an individual than perhaps lies in the hands of the vast majority of the members of this House and the Senate. An arrest involving the action of bricking, which all honourable members will realise is the falsifica­ tion of evidence, or even an arrest based on the personal reaction of a policeman to the behaviour of a person being apprehended can have an effect on a person's life which goes with him or her to the grave. Even the wrongful stopping of a person along the road for a suspected motor offence can have an effect on that person's life at a later I said earlier that I see this legislation as ideal, and it is my fervent wish that every State govern­ ment, irrespective of its political persuasion, study the contents of this legislation, which should be an example to the police forces of the nation. I have long held the view that in a number of occu­ pations one simply cannot win. Those occu­ pations cannot be free of controversy, and do not always have the respect of the public. Politics is one of those arenas. The public will always be div­ ided. The lot of a policeman is not that much different. With politicians, a love-hate relation­ ship exists. The same applies to the police force. A person in trouble cannot ring a policeman quickly enough. A person free of trouble is likely to be either highly critical of police force actions or praiseworthy. The community divides on that subject. Not everybody loves the copper. I think in the Sydney Daily Telegraph today a cartoon showed policemen combing Kings Cross. Some­ one popping up through a manhole-that represented the underworld-said something to the effect: 'We are trying to keep undesirables out of this district. Why don't you beat off?' In a nutshell, I am saying that a policeman will not always be given credit and be on top. How­ ever, one of the inescapable facts is that there are members of the police force who will let the team down. There are policemen who will put their lives at total risk. Many have paid the supreme sacrifice in their efforts to protect John Citizen or save him from one of the accidents about which is we read from time to time. Many have laid down their lives. I think that overall the police forces of this country have given far more to the com­ munity than they have ever asked for in return. However, as with the proverbial barrel of apples, there is always a rotten one. This legislation gives the aggrieved John Citizen the opportunity to re­ port an injustice that he believes has been perpetrated. This legislation will leave open the way for in­ volvement by the Ombudsman. It is opportune to reflect that the role of the Ombudsman since the creation of his position not so many years ago has been greatly enlarged. When a situation gets hot it seems to suit governments of all political per­ suasions to write a reference in legislation to the Ombudsman so he can settle the matter. The com­ bination of the involvement of the Ombudsman and the Internal Investigation Division of the Australian Federal Police will go a long way towards ensuring that where a rotten apple causes an overall poor reflection on a police force that rotten apple will have to answer to somebody at some time. One of the facts of life that I have stage. come to appreciate as I make my way through my three score years and ten is that 100 men can do something, but if one man does the wrong thing the public-including all members of this House-will spend more time talking about that one man who has done the wrong thing than about the 99 people who have spent their lives doing the right or good thing. Mr Barry Jones-Mark Antony's oration said the same thing, but not so eloquently.

Speaker: Mr DONALD CAMERON
Title: RACIAL DISCRIMINATION
text: Yes, Mr Deputy Speaker. I appreciate the interjection. Perhaps it is every 2,000-odd years that a man with similar wisdom passes through this world. As I was say­ ing, this legislation allows that rotten apple to be torn from the barrel. I believe the respect in which the Australian Federal Police Force is presently held will grow as a result of this legislation. I do not wish to repeat the aspects of the legislation which were outlined by the Minister for Employ­ ment and Youth Affairs ( Mr Viner) in his second reading speech and by other speakers, but I make a special appeal to all the State Ministers of police, including the Queensland Minister for Local Government, Main Roads and Police, the Honourable Russell Hinze, to examine this legis­ lation closely to see what it offers and to balance in their minds the criticism which is directed to their police forces with the high respect in which the Australian Federal Police is held. In so doing they should remember that even though the Aus­ tralian Federal Police Force is held on a very high pinnacle, this Parliament sees this legislation as being necessary. Indeed, I believe the Whitlam Government in 1 975 attempted to introduce simi­ lar legislation · and it was the eclipse of that reign which caused the legislation to go into limbo. Two or three years after that this Government recog­ nised that there was still a need for this legislation. Whilst we can all allude to experiences that we have had with various police forces, I believe it is probably appropriate that I do not introduce mat­ ters of a personal nature. I conclude by simply reminding the various State governments that this legislation is setting a new standard and providing a new opportunity for the Australian people to re­ port their grievances and to feel assured that their grievances against the police will be fully inves­ tigated. That in itself not only protects the Aus­ tralian public but also ensures the enshrinement of tht': high standard which so many of the nation's policemen endeavour to attain but which is so often eroded by the actions of one or two irresponsible individuals who should have never been given the power in the first place. My final observation is one that I made earlier in my comments, namely, that so many policemen fail to realise that in their hands more than in those of me in this Parliament lies the power to destroy or to make so many individual lives in our community. Occasionally some of them truly fumble that ball which causes irreparable damage to be inflicted upon the lives of people who are basically as decent if not better than themselves.

Speaker: Dr KLUGMAN
Title: RACIAL DISCRIMINATION
text: Prospect) (9.35)-I rise on the Opposition side of the House to support this legislation because I see it as an improvement. As the last honourable member who spoke, the honourable member for Fadden ( Mr Donald Cameron) , said it is an improvement even on much of the State legislation. J am not aware of all the legislation in the States but I am aware of the legislation in NSW and I must admit that this i� an ' improvement on that. Let me quickly refresh the memories of honourable members as to what ,this Bill when dealing with the handling of compla ints against members of the Australian Federal Police actually proposes could be done. The second read­ ing speech of the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs ( Mr Viner) reads: A complaint by a member of the public as to police conduct may be made to a police officer or to the Ombudsman; where made to a police officer, the Ombudsman mllst be notified. I think that is an important point. It further states: Complaints as to practices and procedures of the force will ordinarily be investigated by the Ombudsman. That refers to general practices and procedures and not specific complaints against an individual member of the Police Force. The speech continues: Other complaints as to the police, that is to say, complaints as to conduct of individual officers, will be investigated in­ itially by the Internal Investigation Division previously mentioned. That is, the Internal Investigation Division which is set up in the police force. The speech continues: If the Ombudsman is dissatisfied with the report of the Investigatin Division on a complaint, he may ask for a further investigation by the Investigation Division or he may carry out an investigation by his own office. I think that is a very important point and I will refer to it again when I deal with the criticism of what the Ombudsmen in other States are doing. The speech continues: The Minister may, on his own initiative, establish a special inquiry into any matter relating to the Force. . . . The Ombudsman may recommend that criminal or disciplinary charges should be brought against a member; if the Commissioner does not agree with the recommendation, the matter shall be referred to the Attorney-General, who shall decide what charges, if any, should be brought. Criminal charges against a police officer will be brought in the ordinary courts; disciplinary complaint from a member of the public will be dealt with by the Federal Police Disciplinary Tribunal to be established under the legislation; I will not go into details as to what the exact method of appeals and so on is, but I think basi­ cally the important point is that there is a method for investigating the Police Force. One of the great difficulties when one is dealing with com­ plaints against the Police Force is that there is no­ body in the community adequately capable of investigating complaints, apart from the Police Force itself. It is a problem that has arisen in Australia and it is a problem which, probably be­ cause we have some similarity with the United States of America and the United Kingdom, has repeatedly been portrayed in films and television programs dealing with policemen who have transgressed the law or people who have made al­ legations against those policemen. I think it is an important improvement that there is provision for the Ombudsman to investigate the problems. Let me quote from the report of the Ombudsman of NSW for the year ended 30 June 1 979. It is the latest printed report but not the latest report pre­ pared. The Ombudsman, Mr Smithers, is a fairly conservative gentleman who is about to retire. He is certainly not an extremely radical person who tends to criticise the Police Force unnecessarily. In the report he states: I have experienced some feelings out my functions under the Act as the powers of investigation are very different to those under the Ombudsman Act. He is talking about investigating the police. He continues: Under that Act I can obtain authority, inspect papers, obtain reports, enter premises and interview anyone and I can carry out a formal investigation if I think it warranted. None of these powers apply under the provisions of the Police Regulation (Allegations of Miscon­ duct) Act. My function under that Act is restricted. I receive complaints, making a decision as to whether there should be an investigation or endeavour to conciliate if it might be ap­ propriate. I then refer the Investigation, I receive a report from him, I decide whether it is properly investigated, and when the investigation is completed then decide whether the complaint has been sus­ tained or not and report accordingly. Under this Act---That is the New South Wales ActI do not investigate in the full sense, I merely act in a super­ visory capacity and finally report to the complaint on the re­ sult of the investigation.
