Speaker: Dr EDWARDS
Title: RACIAL DISCRIMINATION
text: Berowra) (9.50)-- Unlike my Op­ honourable friend, the member for Prospect (Dr Klugman) , who just concluded his speech, I enter this debate as an unashamed advocate and sup­ porter of the Australian police forces. I would like to stress the words of the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) in introducing the Bill in the Senate. He said: The Bill should be regarded as in no way a reflection on the Australian Federal Police or its members who, with the fewest possible exceptions, perform their difficult tasks with honesty, zeal and devotion to duty. Any police force, and I think the Australian Fed­ eral Police in particular, has a difficult and exact­ ing task to perform which often involves personal danger. As Gilbert of Gilbert and Sullivan fame put it: 'A policeman's lot is not a happy one'. I re­ peat, the Minister said this Bill should in no way be regarded as a reflection on the force or on its high reputation for honesty, effectiveness and de­ votion to duty. In the few remarks that I want to address to the House I wish to refer to the point that the honour­ able member for Prospect raised concerning the use of tapes. I would like to say something about the whole issue of the adapting of police methods to modern technology and in particular to micro­ electronic technology based on the silicon chip. Perhaps this is particularly appropriate on the day when the Minister for the Capital Territory ( Mr Hodgman) has just announced a project by the National Semiconductor company loo king towards the setting up of a chip facility in the Aus­ tralian Capital Territory. In this respect [ have in mind in particular the desirability of police officers using tape recorders, not video equip­ ment, in investigative and interrogation situations. In a spirited debate concerning the much malig­ ned police 'verbal' on Sydney radio only last Friday, Detective Sergeant Tony Lauer, the Presi­ dent of the New South Wales Police Association, finished his remarks by saying: Then the only fair thing to do would be to provide the 9,000 policemen in New South Wales with a tape recorder. With that his radio opponent, barrister Shaun Flood, heartily agreed. In my view, that is bang on. I am certain that the great majority of cases in the long run would be to the benefit of police forces and not hindrance although I am aware many police officers would initially see it as such. T am convin­ ced that a very significant contribution would made to police credibility-this is the key thing-if in fact there were a tape recorder every policeman's pocket. A small recorder would be the honest policeman's-and that means the overwhelming majority of policemen-best de­ fence in a complaint situation and in all other aspects of investigative and interrogative police work. Also it would be of great value in sub­ sequent court recordings. The Minister for Administrative Services ( Mr Newman) in his second reading speech, and my tively colleague the honourable member for Fadden ( Mr Donald Cameron) a few moments ago, ac­ knowledged the contribution that His Honour Justice Michael Kirby's Law Reform Commission made to the proposals in the legislation. Only recently-at the time of the last week of members sitting-in a speech to an international forum of police. forensic scientists, Mr Justice Kirby stressed the importance of taped evidence in courts. He spoke of sound recordings-and possibly video Act recordingsas potentially 'a tremendous weapon' in the fight against crime. r am sure that is absolutely right. What I am stressing is that all along the line, from investigat­ ory discussions in the field, through interrogation, to the courts, it is the credibility of the police which stands to gain. I am certain that police officers, understandably initially suspicious such gadgetry, particularly the pocket recorder [ have talked about, would come to see the gains all round in combating crime and in underwriting police credibility, and would come to see that these gains would far outweigh the disadvantages. A report of a British royal commission in January this year, along with other sources, points to problems in this area-the honourable member for Prospect pointed to some of these. There are two main problems firstly, the cost, and, secondly, the area of authenticating tapes, of preventing the tampering with and editing of tapes. Those are problems which I am confident-indeed I know­ are not beyond the scope of modern micro­ electronic technology. In this matter, therefore, I believe the ball is in the court of police officers at all levels. I believe they should accept the aid of each of modern technology and gain the benefits in terms of the more effective combating of crime and-I cannot stress this too much-the gains in the area of police credibility which this technology offers.

Speaker: Mrs KELLY
Title: RACIAL DISCRIMINATION
text: Canberra) ( 1 0.2) -1 speak in in support of both of these BiIls, the Australian Fed­ this eral Police Amendment Bill 1981 and the Com­ a plaints (Australian Federal Police) BiIl 198 1 . 1 believe they will provide a workable system whereby the rights of police officers and the pub­ be lic are protected. The appeals provisions for members of the public to make complaints against in police provide several avenues by which action may be taken. The public may appeal either to the Ombudsman or to the Internal Investigation Div­ ision of the Australian Federal Police. Further provision is made for the responsible Minister to order a special investigation of a specific com­ plaint. The detailed procedures set down for the investigation of any complaint should ensure that all such matters are handled thoroughly and effec­ while at the same time preserving the rights of both the police and public. Where any com­ plaint is made to a police officer, the Ombudsman Mr must be notified. Through this legislation the Ombudsman's role is strengthened and extended, and should result in improved safeguards for of the public in their dealings with the The rights of citizens are further improved under the provisions of clause 4 of the Bill for an to amend the Australian Federal Police Act 1 979. Under this clause, members of the police force must at all times wear identification numbers on the front of their uniforms and there is provision for a penalty of $500 for failure to do so. The arrangements for the investigation of force complaints by means of the Ombudsman, the Internal Investigation Division of the Australian of Federal Police and ministerial action should ensure that a n effective mechanism has been established. The rights of police officers have been enhanced by provision for the Commonwealth to assume vicarious liability for the actions of police in the performance of their duties. In this way, the Commonwealth, like all other employers, will be liable in respect of tort committed by an em­ ployee. In large measure the objectives of the Law Reform Commission report of 1 978 have been enacted, with minor variations resulting from the creation of the Australian Federal Police in 1 979. These measures will be welcomed by members of the police force as well as the general community. This legislation is the culmination of a lengthy procedure for the establishment of the Australian Federal Police Force. We may recall that the pro­ posal to establish a national police force was reac­ tivated following the bombing of the Hilton Hotel in Sydney on 1 3 February 1 978. Sir Robert Mark's inquiry into the organisation of police re­ sources in the Commonwealth was an urgent mat­ ter and the report was tabled on 1 3 April 1 978. The Government acted swiftly to set up a task force to give effect to its in-principle decision to establish a single federal police force incorporat­ ing the existing Australian Capital Territory and Commonwealth police forces. The Australian Federal Police Bill 1 979 became law in June 1 979, and the force was established with Sir Colin Woods as commissioner. The Bills under debate today will extend the effectiveness of our police force. They provide members of the general public with additional safeguards and rights of appeal in their dealings with the police. The rights of police officers are protected throughout the complaints procedure and are further strengthened under the provisions whereby Commonwealth liability is extended. I want to refer briefly to the policewho operate in the Australian Capital Territory. They have ex­ tremely close relations with the community at all levels. The new amalgamated Australian Federal Police has continued the tradition of the previous forces and has provided the community with an excellent service. To give one example, on 28 February this year officers of the police force in the Australian Capital Territory held a fete on be­ half of the Multiple Sclerosis Association. This fete had wide support from members of the Aus­ tralian Federal Police. I think this demonstrates their commitment to work very closely with the community. I have noticed that over the last couple of weeks members of the Australian Fed­ eral Police have participated in the Canberra Week festivities. There is a regular community broadcast program on our local television station, Channel 7. These are just examples which demon­ strate the involvement of the police force in the Australian Capital Territory. One point I think needs to be emphasised. Sec­ tion 69 of the Australian Federal Police Act 1 979 provides for the establishment of a police liaison advisory committee for the Australian Capital Territory. That committee has not been set up, despite the fact that the legislation became law in June 1 979. In March 1 980 the Minister for the Capital Territory sent a message to the House of Assembly regarding the proposed committee, seeking the Assembly's advice on the proposal to establish such a committee. The House of Assem­ bly called for the early establishment of the police liaison advisory committee. The proposed com­ mittee is to be chaired by a commissioner and will have five members of the House of Assembly on it. Its functions are set out by regulation. They are to encourage community awareness and under­ standing of such functions of the Australian Fed­ eral Police as relate to the provision of police ser­ vices in the Australian Capital Territory and to advise the Minister on those. I ask the Attorney­ General (Senator Durack) to give urgent con­ sideration to the establishment of this advisory committee. The recommendation for its establish­ ment is set out clearly in legislation and does need to be activated. I must also provide a cautionary note in re­ lation to the police services in the Australian Capital Territory. When the Australian Federal Police was established, the Government gave a commitment that the police officers of the Aus­ tralian Capital Territory and the community would not be disadvantaged by the establishment of the Australian Federal Police. The Australian Capital Territory was to be the responsibility of a separate deputy commissioner with certain auton­ omy. However I understand that lately the officers of that division have been used on national matters. For example, I have had infor­ mation that about 200 officers from various parts of Australia are being sent to the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting, but the big ma­ jority of those are from the Australian Capital Territory. I hope that if officers from the Terri­ tory are being used for these national functions, the Australian Capital Territory force will get compensation. I conclude by recommending to the Minister that the police liaison advisory committee be set up immediately and that the Federal Government continue to retain the identity of an Australian Capital Territory community police force. Speaker: Mr JOHN BROWN
Title: AUSTRALIAN TOURIST COMMISSION
text: Parramatta) ( l 0. 1 1 ) - The Opposition does not intend to oppose the Australian Tourist Commission Amendment Bill. However, it intends to take the opportunity to point out the Government's deficiencies in the whole tourist industry. No one, least of all a rational party such as the Australian Labor Party-which might be of some interest to some honourable members opposite-could argue against the need to increase the number of com­ missioners from nine to 1 0 or to increase the number of Territory representatives from two to three. I am pleased to see that the Minister for Capital Territory ( Mr Hodgman) is sitting at the table, because we consider that Canberra is one of the very important tourist destinations of Australia for many reasons which I need not underline at the moment. In fact, my colleague, the honourable member for Canberra ( Mrs Kelly) would like to speak in a fuller fashion later in the debate about the charms and delights of Canberra. The Opposition is quite delighted that the number of commissioners is being increased to accommodate the Australian Capital Territory and the Northern Territory. Of course, a good deal of their revenue comes from tourism. Such moves are indeed sensible. So too is the third aim of the Bill to bring the financial provisions of the Act into line with legislation covering comparable Third Reading statutory authorities. I hope that this Government will be looking towards redressing the very sexist imbalance of the Australian Tourist Commission. Given the comments of the Minister for the Capital Terri­ tory over the last couple of days on sexism issues, I am sure he would back me up in that regard. At present there are nine commissioners of whom Second Reading only one is a female. Does that reflect community participation in tourism? Of course it does not. The Commission will be the poorer while this state of affairs exists. I would like to come directly to the question of the economics of tourism. The most recent and comprehensive report is that put out by the Bu­ Third Reading reau of Industry Economics. It is fairly old be­ cause the latest figures that are available are those for 1 973-74. I would like to refer to the fourth re­ search report entitled The Economic Significance of Tourism in Australia in 1 979'. There is very little doubt that tourism impacts dramatically on our economy. In 1 973-74 tourism contributed 2.6 per cent of gross domestic product. It employed Second Reading 2.4 per cent of the work force and accounted for 3.2 per cent of indirect tax revenue. These figures, which have been referred to before by the Minis­ ter for industry and Commerce ( Sir Phillip Lynch) place tourism at just about the level of the motor manufacturing industry and just behind the mining industry. Obviously it is a very significant industry. The Bureau of Industrial Economics further predicts that by 1 98 5 overseas tourist spending in Australia will rise from 20 per cent to 40 per cent of total tourism spending. That is the amount con­ tributed by overseas visitors. By 1 985 employment in the tourist industry will increase from 2.4 per cent to about 8 per cent of the work force and will add 60,000 new jobs. Its contribution to the gross the domestic product will rise by 80 per cent to about 4.5 per cent of our GDP. Obviously, as is shown by those bald figures, tourism is a very significant industry. A great deal of informed and uninformed de­ bate has taken place on the possible tourist boom. One thing that is certain is that it is one of the prime growth industries and, as such, we in Australia ought to be capitalising on the expan­ sion. Mr Deputy Speaker, the fact is-you will excuse the tourist pun-we are missing the boat quite dramatically. Including the payment for fares, the amount spent in a year by the millions of international travellers on tourist related indus­ tries is estimated to be the staggering figure of $325,000m, or more than six times the annual value of Australia's gross domestic product. The sad fact is that Australia currently extracts much less than one per cent of all international tourist expenditures-in fact about 0.3 per cent, a very tiny proportion of the tourist dollar. That is some­ thing that the Opposition deplores. Even in the Pacific area, where I would have thought just as a matter of fact that Australia would be the leader, our share of tourism is drop­ ping. In 1 970 our share of tourism in this market was 4.7 per cent. By 1 978 it had dropped to 3.8 per cent, showing just how rapidly we were losing out to the other Asian Pacific countries who are so much more aware of tourism as an industry than we are. The honourable member for Bowman ( Mr Jull) is going to join in this debate. I am sure that he shares the views of the Opposition and the optimism that it would like to express in tourism as a growth industry in the future.

Speaker: Mr JOHN BROWN
Title: AUSTRALIAN TOURIST COMMISSION
text: He is a very good member; I agree with the Minister. I do not know what he is doing on the other side of the House. As a result of our failure to exploit the Pacific area, a great many off-shore venues for conventions, sem­ inars, workshops and other events have become a great deal more attractive than Australia. Local tour operators, convention venue entrepreneurs, tourism support industries and the airlines them­ selves face a great loss of business because of this. For instance, seven nights with all travel and ac­ commodation expenses from Sydney cost less than $360 in Fiji and less than $300 in New Zealand. But five nights all-in cost about $400 in Hobart and more than $700 in Darwin; about 30 per cent higher than, for example, Singapore. In the last Budget the Fraser Government allocated to tourism less than $20m. It is interest­ ing to note that the Government gets back $ l Om of that $20m every 1 2 months in gateway tax, the $ 10 tax it collects from people leaving Australia. So the net contribution to tourism in the last Budget was around the $ 10m mark. I mentioned previously that this industry contributes as much as the motor industry. When we look at the hun­ dreds of millions of dollars expended in promoting that industry I wonder just what the Government is doing in failing to promote tourism as an indus­ try. I know that the argument is quite reasonable that without manufacturing industries we would not have as many people in work; we would not have people wanting holidays; and that tourism perhaps would suffer. I think there is a great im­ balance between the $ 1 Om net for tourism and the hundreds of millions of dollars expended in many manufacturing industries. This Government is neglecting to foster an im­ portant industry. It lacks the imagination and the foresight necessary to capitalise on this growing industry, not only an industry which is economi­ cally significant but also one which gives so much pleasure to the community. The whole leisure in­ dustry is crying out for the type of leadership that an entrepreneurial government could give it, such as was given it by the Labor Government from 1 972 to 1 975. 1 give credit to the present Minister for Industry and Commerce. At least he has some understanding of the tourist industry and has taken some positive steps in recent times. The Bill we are now debating is part of the new-found interest in the tourism business, but it might well be a case of too little too late. I ask the Govern­ ment where it was in the tourism area from 1 975 to 1 978. Perhaps it might say it was on holidays. If it was on a holiday it was doing a lot better than many other people who could not afford a holiday. According to figures from the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development, growth in tourism in Australia fell last year. The increase in the number of overseas visitors arriv­ ing in Australia was 1 5.9 per cent compared with a growth rate of 25.9 per cent in 1 979. Revenue growth from those tourists fell also. In 1 979 the figure was 27.4 per cent compared with 19. 1 per cent last year. In the same OECD report there is a note of optimism that as the world economy im­ proves so will interest in travel pick up and so will we see a stronger growth rate in the tourist indus­ try. This is in line with predictions previously quoted from the BIE report that by 1 985!overseas tourist spending in Australia will rise from the , present 20 per cent to 40 per cent of total tOUrIsm expenditure. Will we be geared up fon this up­ surge of interest in travel-not just travel but the whole spectrum of the leisure industrJ'? I In 1 972 under the Whitlam Government, in those years of Camelot in Australia, the people of Australia saw the advent of the first Federal Min­ istry for Tourism and Recreation under the direc­ tion of the late Frank Stewart and with it the rec­ ognition that there was a vital role for government in this area, In that time the role of the Australian Tourist Commission was expanded and with it went a brief to step up the promotion of Australia overseas and on the domestic market through the program 'Australia-Land of things to see and do', By 1 975 some $2.34m had been provided in grants and loans for the development of man­ made attractions such as Sovereign Hill, Old Syd­ ney Town, Lachlan Vintage Village and Port Arthur. To the purist, these man-made attractions might seem gauche and almost artificial, but they are essential ingredients in an overall tourism strategy. Our heritage, the colonial frontier people that we were, is encapsulated in places such as Sovereign Hill and Old Sydney Town. These places give Australians of today as well as overseas visitors a dioramic view of our past. Of course it is preferable to visit these man-made at­ tractions in conjunction with the real thing. I might say that that is nowhere more evident than in my home town of Parramatta. In Parramatta some of Australia's real antiquity reposes. Within a radius of less than half a mile exists a cottage that was built by John Macarthur back in I 79 1 - it is the oldest house in Australia; it is still standing-MONICA

Speaker: Mr JOHN BROWN
Title: AUSTRALIAN TOURIST COMMISSION
text: I suggest to you, Mr Deputy Speaker, that when I spoke about man­ made and artificial types of tourist attractions, I was suggesting that in Parramatta we have a mar­ vellous collection of real antiquity which is some­ thing to which overseas visitors should be attracted. The reason I mentioned it was that I was hoping that this Government might be pre­ pared to consider subsidising the development of the tourism industry within this part of Sydney. The three cottages to which I wish to refer are: Elizabeth Farm, which was a house built by John Macarthur and where in fact the Australian wool industry started; within 100 yards of that is a house called Experiment Farm Cottage, which was built by James Ruse-that is where the Aus­ tralian wheat industry commenced-and within a range of a quarter of a mile is Hambledon Cot­ tage, which was built by John Macarthur for his daughter, Elizabeth, in 1 8 1 5. Sitting in one small area is a marvellous collection of Australia's real antiquity, looking for development, looking for the injection of government funds to bring this lit­ tle group of cottages up to something that is really significant. I suggest that to you, Mr Deputy Speaker, in passing. I now return to the man-made tourist facilities. We may rave all we like about the grandeur and beauty of Australia's natural attractions, but the fact is that very few international tourists seek them out. I suspect that the cost of domestic air fares, despite the Minister's protestations to the contrary, are the prime re:1son for the neglect of our far-flung natural attractions. I am supporled in my claim that such places as Ayers Rock and the Great Barrier Reef are neglected by overseas visitors by a Qantas Airways Ltd survey con­ ducted on departing foreign tourists in 1 973. This survey revealed, quite disappointingly, that Ayers Rock was visited by a mere 2 per cent and the Great Barrier Reef, which is in your home State, Mr Deputy Speaker, by only 4 per cent of such visitors. That is rather depressing when we con­ sider that the Great Barrier Reef-I know that the honourable member for Bowman has spoken very eloquently on this in the past-is one of the really great attractions of this world. It is one of the wonders of the world. It is a really magnificent attraction for tourists and yet only 4 per cent of our international visitors are going there. Of course, the two-airline agreement which is to be updated will entrench this position probably for another 1 0 years unless the Minister in charge of tourism is able to convince his colleagues to do otherwise. Whilst it is true to say that this situation might have improved since 1 973, it is still evident that most foreign tourists spend their time and money in the capital cities, with Sydney being the most visited. I could not really blame them for that. We are talking about the great cosmopolitan cities of the world, and of course Sydney is just slightly ahead of Canberra. Really, it is one of the most beautiful cities of the world. It is no wonder that overseas visitors go there in droves. I suggest that by investing money in the likes of Sovereign Hill and Old Sydney Town we ensure some diversification of the tourist dollars---a dis­ tribution to regional areas, if you like. I imagine that the coalition government would favour such a strategy. Yet we have seen little, if any, support for the continuatio!l of the former Labor Govern­ ment's initiatives. Who would deny the employment opportuni­ ties created by these man-made, operations; that is, regional job opportunities, which is giving em­ ployment to people in country areas where unem­ ployment is worse? Also to be considered is the ac­ commodation which springs up around these attractions and with it even more employment opportunities. Tourism and leisure activities filter right through the economic system. The BIE re­ port's conclusions stated: . . . tourism is already of Australian economy with direct or indirect effects on almost every industry. It has been stated that tourism or leisure, or the two together, make a contribution to all 1 09 in­ dustry groups in Australia. Any Australian Government ignores tourism at its peril. Given the evidence of all the economic indicators which show the value of tourism to the national econ­ omy, I put it to you, Mr Deputy Speaker, that there is an overwhelming argument for the re­ instatement of the Department of Tourism and Recreation. Certainly, after 1 98 3 when Labour is in office, we will be looking to do just that. By that time, the leisure industry will have grown to such proportions that it will not be able to be ignored, as seems to be presently the case. Let me list some of the reasons why I believe that nothing less than a fully operational Federal department is capable of effectively harnessing the exciting potentials of the leisure industry. Quite naturally, my top priority is employment opportunity. Here, in an area of our lives which affects so many other industries, a Federal government has a unique opportunity to stimulate the economy and create employment simply by investing in a man-made attractions and other types of tourist facilities. Leisure is a very labour intensive area. The BIE report pointed this out. Areas such as restaurants, hotels and clubs are very labour intensive. I point out to anybody who is interested that the reason New South Wales has the lowest unemployment rate in Australia is to a great extent because of the leisure industry which has built up there. Presently there are 3 3,000 permanent jobs pro­ vided in registered clubs in New South Wales with some 1 00,000 more temporary jobs. It is. very un­ likely that anybody wjll ever create a machine that will make beds or serve meals. That is the beauty of the leisure industry. It is totally labour intensive. While I am on the subject of labour and the leisure industry, I mention the oft-quoted la­ ment that penalty rates inhibit the industry. A very excellent report was produced by Roger Kirby who was then the boss of Travelodge Australia Ltd. He pointed out that it is a total furphy to suggest that penalty rates are holding back the accommodation industry in Australia. It is just wrong. No less a person than Professor Brian Johns, the Director of the BIE, stated: The report showed that the prices of tourist services in Australia are not significantly higher than in other developed countries. Again I quote from a Press release issued by the Minister last year when he visited Tokyo. He cited figures from a world survey conducted by the considerable significance to the economic research department of the Union Bank of Switzerland. He stated: Our tourist industry can compete favourably with other alternative tourist destinations around the world . . . The general level of prices in Sydney was ranked lower than those in 33 of the 45 cities (surveyed). The important and most significant part of that is that we can provide such competitive prices within a framework of a high living standard. There is absolutely no reason why Australian workers ought to lower their living standards in order to attract the tourist dollar. Consequently there is no good reason why penalty rates should be abandoned. They were hard won. Debate interrupted. text: La Trobe) ( 10.35)-Often in debates in this House the problems of the aged pensioners of our community are neglected. r take the opportunity tonight to describe the debilitat­ ing experiences of one of my constituents, Mr Albert Bruce, in his successful attempt to avoid losing the fringe benefits of his age pension. In May 1980 Mr Bruce and his wife received a com­ bined United Kingdom age pension of $69 a week which was $ 1 more than the $68 they were al­ lowed to earn before they lost their fringe benefits. Acting on the advice of the Department of Social Security, Mr Bruce immediately wrote to the United Kingdom pension authorities requesting that his total benefit be reduced to $68 a week. This was done by the United Kingdom Depart­ ment of Health and Social Security. Following this desperate measure Mr Bruce was most upset to find that the Department of Social Security im­ mediately invoked a provision of the Social Ser­ vices Act which states that when the Director­ General is of the opinion that a pensioner has directly or indirectly deprived himself of income in order to qualify for or obtain a pension at a higher rate he may deem the amount involved to be income for a period of 1 2 months of the deprivation. Mr Bruce then wrote back to the Department pointing out that his United Kingdom pension had been reduced. Honourable member's should note that this was a reduction of only $ 1 a week. His pension had been reduced in order that he would not lose what were to him his essential fringe benefits. The Department then informed him that as a result of income received from in­ vestments plus exchange rate fluctuations relating to the United Kingdom pension the combined in­ come of him and his wife meant that their Aus­ tralian pensions must be substantially reduced and they would lose their fringe benefits. Mr Bruce, after some considerable correspondence, was able to prove to the Department that he no longer received investment income but the De­ partment stood firm on the exchange rate require­ ments. After months of wearying disputation Mr Bruce then sought the help of the Ombudsman and his Federal member. Finally, in August the Department of Social Security admitted its errors and Mr and Mrs Bruce's pensions and their fringe benefits were restored. My main purpose in bringing up this matter to­ night is in order that Mr Bruce's battle with an un­ yielding legislative machine should not be in vain. His case is not an isolated one. I have had a con­ siderable number of my constituents complain to me about the penalty provisions. Whilst it is true that the Department does not stand in a good light in the case I have mentioned I do not wish to blame public servants for bad government. Many thousands of age pensioners are suffering re­ ductions in pensions and losing their fringe benefits as a result of these penny-pinching penal provisions. I call on the Government to revoke these savage and inhumane means test provisions of the Social Services Act and to restore some measure of dignity and security to many Aus­ tralians in their retirement years.

text: Casey) ( 10.40)-I wish to raise a case concerning an application by a con­ stituent of mine for a Service pension. The con­ stituent is Mr B. R. Smyth of lot l 30B Chum Creek Road, Toolangi, Victoria. Mr Smyth re­ cently was denied a Service pension after attain­ ing 60 years of age. The rejection of his appli­ cation was based on the contention that his service did not satisfy the theatre of war pro­ visions required to qualify for such a pension. However, I point out that Mr Smyth had pre­ viously been given written confirmation by the Department of Veterans' Affairs that he had the required theatre of war service. The chronology of events is this: Mr Smyth originally submitted a let­ ter dated 2 July 1 980-in fact he was personally interviewed-in which he inquired about his eligi­ bility. Several weeks later, on 22 August, a letter from the Department of Veterans' Affairs was sent to him confirming that he had the required theatre of war service to apply for a Service pen­ sion. I seek leave of the House to incorporate in Hansard the brief letter that was received from the Department of Veterans' Affairs on this subject. Leave granted. The document read as follows22nd August 1 980 Mr B. R. Smyth 8 Eagle Rise Lower Templestowe, Vic. 3107 Dear Mr Smyth It has now been confirmed that you have the required Theatre of War service to make application for a service pen­ sion on attaining sixty years of age. The relevant forms are enclosed for your benefit. Yours sincerely T. M. STEPHENS Deputy Commissioner

Speaker: Mr FALCONER
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: T thank the House. The let­ ter to Mr Smyth quite clearly states: It has now been confirmed that you have the required Theatre of War service to make application for a Service pen­ sion on attaining sixty years of age. The letter attached relevant forms which he was invited to send in for his benefit. On the basis of that advice Mr Smyth made arrangements to re­ tire from his work. In fact, that is the basis of the problem he now faces. He submitted the relevant application forms and subsequently received a let­ ter from the Department of Veterans' Affairs, dated 3 December, in which he was advised that his service did not satisfy the theatre of war pro­ visions. Apparently, at the specific time he was in an area of active service or an area of war oper­ ations that area was not deemed to be a theatre of war. On that technicality he was denied a Service pension. The problem is that he earlier had received written confirmation from the Depart­ ment that he had the required theatre of war ser­ vice. He received that confirmation six or seven weeks after originally making inquiries. One would have thought that it would be a reasonable expectation that appropriate checks of records would be made in that time. My constituent finds himself in a difficult pos­ ition. He retired from his work on the basis of what he thought to be his eligibility for a Service pension. That has now been denied to him be­ cause of subsequent examinations by the Depart­ ment of Veterans' Affairs. I appreciate that every­ one involved in this matter has acted in good faith but I think that the Department, having made a mistake in writing to my constituent and confirm­ ing that he had the relevant theatre of war service, should now bear the consequences. The Govern­ ment should in some way seek to make up to Mr Smyth what he would otherwise have qualified for in the form of a Service pension. I believe that in justice some way around this problem ought to be found so that Mr Smyth can gain the benefits of what he thought he would receive.

Speaker: Mrs CHILD
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: Henty) ( 10.54) -1 would like to speak to the House tonight about two young men called Robert and Bill. Robert lost a leg when he was 14 years old. Since then he has had an artificial leg which he finds very difficult to wear because it gives him a very bad back, as do crutches also. After he lost his leg he could not settle back in school so, quite unqualified at 1 5 years, he took a job. The only one he could get was driving a fork lift machine, but when there was not enough work for the machine he had to go down into the store room and help out there. He could not cope with the lifting involved so he had to leave that position. As he could not get another job he applied for the dole. He got a job with a tow truck company. This involved long hours, dis­ poor pay and offered no overtime for weekend work. He stayed asJong as he could put up with it but then had to leave and go back on the dole again. He was on the dole for two years but not once during that time was a job offered to him by the Commonwealth Employment Service. His mother's mother took ill in Queanbeyan. The son drove her up to visit and then went back again. On the day he was away from home a field officer called to see him. The husband rang and explained where he was, what he was doing and when he would be home but Robert was taken off the dole. It took a hell of a long fight to get him back on it again. He was taken off the dole be­ cause he was out of Victoria for whatever reason or however briefly. It took six weeks to get Robert back on the dole. Three years ago he applied for an invalid pension. He was knocked back. He has not worked now for over I 2 months. In the last seven years of misery and pain he has worked for about 1 2 months. Every time he applied for a job he was told that they needed someone who was not handicapped. Robert is not handicapped; he is disabled by the loss of his leg. His handicap is given to him by us-by the society in which he lives. We applied for the pension for him again but he was knocked back again. As his mother points out: 'Because he has lost a leg he does not count as a human being any more'. She also said that Robert had reached the stage where he goes down with his dole form and feels as though he is a criminal. Robert is 2 1 . He probably has another 50-odd years in front of him. Is he supposed to live on the dole forever or are we prepared to train Robert and all the Roberts of this world in the work with which they can cope bearing in mind their disabilities? It makes a mockery of the words in the second read­ ing speech earlier tonight by the Minister for Em­ ployment and Youth Affairs ( Mr Viner). The Minister brought out the fact that everyone no matter how disabled he is-physically or mentally-is entitled to a decent standard of liv­ ing, to social security and to the right to live and not just to exist. Robert and all the other Roberts will be interested to hear the Minister's plans for their rights to become as self-reliant as possible. His plans are for them to have economic and social security and to have a chance for a decent level of living because they are certainly not get­ ting these things in today's climate. It is not enough for the Minister to prate about human rights. A government is supposed to do something concrete to help Robert. I shall leave Robert for the moment. Let us have a look at the position of Bill who is 26. He has a long history of mental instability but in be­ tween being institutionalised has fought very hard to work. He is an intelligent man and has held sev­ eral responsible jobs. However, when the stress becomes heavy he loses his job, goes back on the dole and goes back into hospital. Some time ago he tried to commit suicide but simply succeeded in causing himself dreadful damage. It will be years before he is physically fit. Because he was on the dole at the time he gets the sickness benefit only at the rate of unemployment benefit. He needs com­ plete care. He has to be lifted out of bed. He has to be taken to the physiotherapist twice a week. He needs a bedroom, which he has not got. His pen­ sioner mother has a small one-bedroom cottage. Why cannot he go on to the invalid pension at least until he is fit? Why do we have to so humili­ ate and harass those who are least able to bear the burdens? What about Bill's future? What about his human rights? I challenge this Government to take up the responsibility of ensuring that those who are disabled have the right to live and not just to exist; make the Minister's words of today come true. The Government should give them the right to economic security and a decent standard of liv­ ing. This Government is known for its great and humane rhetoric and is condemned for its failure to follow through with action.

text: Macarthur) (1 0.59) In the minute remaining in this adjournment debate I would like to underline the points I made in my speech earlier this evening by quoting from the Budget figures which dramatise the increase in spending on community health services this year. For New South Wales there is an increase from $20Am to $24.9m, a rise of $4.5m on a matching grant basis which represents a 2 1 per cent in­ crease. The new total of $24.9m, as I said earlier, was regarded by the New South Wales Govern­ ment as sufficient at least to maintain the standard last year for community health services in that State. Any cuts in services that have taken place subsequently are entirely due to the inability of the New South Wales Government to keep within its 2 1 per cent higher budget.
